revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=April 2010}} '''Abortion in Panama''' is illegal except in instances that the pregnancy is life-threatening or the health of the woman is at risk, or if the pregnancy is the result of [[rape]] or [[incest]].
== History == A penal code was set in place on September 22, 1982, which penalized illegal abortions. This code is still active today.
In 2005, a poll was conducted with a simple questionnaire. One of the questions asked, "Do you agree or disagree with abortion?" 89.4% of those that answered were against abortions.<ref name="pop.org">http://www.pop.org/00000000147/the-epidemiology-of-abortion-in-pro-life-panama{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to the CIA, based upon the population as a whole, 85% of Panamanians are against abortion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pm.html|title=The World Factbook|work=cia.gov}}</ref> Approximately four-fifths of Panama's population practices [[Roman Catholicism]], which has as its official stance that abortion is murder.
== Legality == In Panama, abortion is illegal with the exception of two circumstances: if the mother's life is endangered by the pregnancy, or if she is the victim of rape or incest.
==Penalties for abortion== The punishment for a woman who has an illegal abortion is one to three years in prison. The punishment for a doctor or other person who performs the procedure with the woman's consent is 3 to 6 years in prison. If the procedure is done without the woman's consent, the punishment is 5 to 10 years in prison. If the woman dies as a result of the abortion, the punishment for the abortionist is 5–10 years in prison. If the woman's husband is found guilty of performing the abortion, the penalties are increased by one sixth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/panama.doc |title=Abortion Policy |publisher=[[United Nations Population Division]] |accessdate=2010-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060220044912/http://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/panama.doc |archivedate=2006-02-20 |df= }}</ref>
==Access to abortion facilities== The only abortions allowed to be performed are done by doctors in government-run hospitals.<ref name="pop.org"/>
==Alternatives to abortion==
===Contraceptives=== Condoms, [[tubal ligation]], and some [[intrauterine devices]] (IUDs) are available at no cost to a woman. Other forms of contraception that require a fee, such as other IUDs and chemical drugs (like the Depo shot), are available, but the woman does not need to get a prescription to obtain them.<ref name="pop.org"/>
===Family planning=== In 1965, the Asociación Panameña para el Planeamiento de la Familia, or (APLAFA), was founded to help women control the size of their families. A private family planning group, APLAFA has gone to great lengths not just to reduce the rate of teen pregnancy, but also to aid pregnant women with pre- and post-natal care for their unwanted pregnancies.<ref>https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/panama.doc {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401064655/https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/panama.doc |date=April 1, 2016 }}</ref> The Panamanian government has also played a constructive role in the family planning movement. It offers services which teach couples about natural birth control methods (such as the ovulation method, the symptothermal method, and the rhythm method),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://familydoctor.org/online/famdocen/home/women/contraceptive/126.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615041506/http://familydoctor.org/online/famdocen/home/women/contraceptive/126.html |archivedate=2010-06-15 |df= }}</ref> as well as modern methods, which many know as "the pill", shots, patches, sterilization, and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov.ph/data/pressrelease/2004/pr0414tx.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115224040/http://www.census.gov.ph//data/pressrelease/2004/pr0414tx.html |archivedate=2009-11-15 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== *[[:Category:Abortion by country|Abortion by country]] *[[Abortion law]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100916175703/http://www.abpanama.com/about-panama/religion-in-panama.php abpanama.com] *[http://www.religioustolerance.org/jud_abor.htm religioustolerance.org] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050916002842/http://pages.prodigy.net/wrjohnston/policy/abortion/ab-panama.html pages.prodigy.net]
{{Abortion in North America}} {{Abortion}}

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/World of Children Awards]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
'''Aidchild''', a [[not-for-profit]] organization incorporated in both [[Uganda]] and the [[United States]], was established in 2000 as a [[hospice]] center for [[orphan]]s living with [[AIDS]] who did not have the care of extended family members. In 2002, it became the first [[pediatric]] facility in Uganda to provide free [[anti-retroviral]] drugs to children. Today,{{When|date=May 2012}} more than 3,000 children have received care and treatment through Aidchild's inpatient and outpatient services, including a laboratory, two clinics, homes and academies in [[Masaka]] and [[Mpigi]], Uganda.
Aidchild is supported by a mix of government and private donors and income-generating activities.
==History== Aidchild was founded by Nathaniel Dunigan. Dunigan first visited Uganda when he was Deputy Director of the Office of the Governor in Tucson, Arizona.<ref name=tucsoncitizen>{{cite news|last=Vanderson|first=Jessie|title=Out of Africa|url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue2/2001/03/22/166614-out-of-africa/ |accessdate=25 April 2012|newspaper=Tucson Citizen|date=22 March 2001}}</ref> A one-month assignment as a volunteer HIV-prevention educator had taken him to Africa where he met many children who were suffering and dying. On his return to the US, he resolved to make a difference, and completed a feasibility study for his Aidchild concept. At the age of 26, he resigned from his job, sold his car and belongings, and moved to Uganda.<ref name=profiles/> He had an initial budget of just $3,500. Two years later, Aidchild was chosen by the Ugandan and American governments as a model of pediatric HIV/AIDS care for the entire continent of Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aim.jsi.com/Docs/annual_report_2003.pdf|publisher=The AIDS/HIV Integrated Model District Programme|title= Annual Report 2003}}</ref> A second center was created just after that, as was a treatment laboratory that has served the needs of more than 3,000 children and adults living with AIDS.
==Social entrepreneurship== Aidchild operates the Equation Gallery, an art gallery and café on the [[Equator]] line in Uganda; Ten Tables, a restaurant and screening room in [[Masaka]], and Aidchild's Terrace Club, a rooftop barbecue venue and boutique hostel.<ref name=profiles/> International travel guides have called the businesses the very best in the whole of Eastern and Central Africa. Clients include international celebrities, Ambassadors, and UN personnel. [[Lonely Planet]] calls Aidchild's Equation Café “first class,” and Oscar winner [[Emma Thompson]] says it is “possibly the best shop on the planet”. The [[Eye (magazine)|''Eye'' magazine]] named Aidchild’s restaurant the best in the nation in 2008.
The organization earns 70% of its own budget from these businesses, and is 100% administratively self-sustained thanks to a Ugandan management team.<ref name=profiles/>
==Nathaniel Dunigan== Dr. Nathaniel Dunigan was raised on the [[Navajo reservation]] in the [[southwestern United States]].<ref name=tucsoncitizen/>
;Work in the United States Dunigan has testified before the United States Congress in Washington, DC<ref>{{cite web|title=AIDS Orphans and Vulnerable Children in Africa|url=http://commdocs.house.gov/committees/intlrel/hfa78801.000/hfa78801_0f.htm|publisher=United States Congress}}</ref> as an expert witness in the identification of best practices of care for orphans living with AIDS, and other vulnerable children in Africa. In 2004, Dunigan was nominated for the World of Children Award. He is the author of "We Are Not Mahogany: Three stories about the male African life." <ref>''We Are Not Mahogany: Three stories about the male African life''. {{ISBN|978-1-4993-3765-5}}</ref>
After living in rural Uganda for nine years, Dunigan completed a master's degree in education at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]], specializing in Human Development and Psychology,<ref name=profiles>{{cite news|last=Andersen|first=Jill|title=From One to Many: Master’s Student Nathaniel Dunigan|url=http://www.gse.harvard.edu/news-impact/2009/12/from-one-to-many-masters-student-nathaniel-dunigan/|accessdate=21 April 2012|newspaper=Harvard Graduate School of Education|date=2 December 2009}}</ref> and a PhD in Leadership and Education at the [[University of San Diego]]’s [[School of Leadership and Education Sciences]] (SOLES) where he was the Dammeyer Fellow.<ref>{{cite web|title=Student Profile|url=http://www.sandiego.edu/soles/programs/leadership_studies/current_student_profiles/doc_student_profiles.php#dunigan|accessdate=21 April 2012}}</ref> He was also a Reynolds Fellow in Social Entrepreneurship at the [[Harvard Kennedy School]]'s [[Center for Public Leadership]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Dunigan |first=Nathaniel |title=My Path to the Reynolds Fellowship |url=http://64.151.79.128/?p=134 |publisher=Harvard Kennedy School |accessdate=21 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208135132/http://64.151.79.128/?p=134 |archivedate=8 February 2011 }}</ref> and winner of the 2010 Harvard HDP Marshal Award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Honors Awarded at 2010 Convocation Ceremony|url=http://www.gse.harvard.edu/news-impact/2010/05/honors-awarded-at-2010-convocation-ceremony/|accessdate=21 April 2012|newspaper=Harvard Graduate School of Education|date=27 May 2010}}</ref>
;Current work Dunigan now divides his time between Uganda and Florida in his role as Chief Executive Officer of Aidchild.
Dunigan has personally adopted more than 100 children in Uganda. He and the Ugandan staff continue to receive new children.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *{{official website|http://www.aidchild.org}}

{{Italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Angelica sinensis'' |image = Dongquai cr.jpg |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Apiales]] |familia = [[Apiaceae]] |genus = ''[[Angelica]]'' |species = '''''A. sinensis''''' |binomial = ''Angelica sinensis'' |binomial_authority = ([[Daniel Oliver|Oliv]].) [[Ludwig Diels|Diels]]<ref>{{GRIN | accessdate = 2012-06-30 }}</ref> |synonyms = {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; | *''Angelica omeiensis'' <small>C.Q.Yuan & R.H.Shan</small> *''Angelica wilsonii'' <small>H.Wolff</small> }} |synonyms_ref = <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/search?q=angelica+sinensis |title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species |accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref> |}}
'''''Angelica sinensis''''', commonly known as '''''dong quai''''' or "'''female [[ginseng]]'''" is a herb from the family [[Apiaceae]], indigenous to [[China]]. ''Angelica sinensis'' grows in cool high altitude mountains in China, Japan, and Korea. The yellowish brown root of the plant is harvested in fall and is a well-known Chinese medicine used over thousands of years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dong quai|url=http://umm.edu/health/medical/altmed/herb/dong-quai|website=University of Maryland Medical Center}}</ref>
==Pharmacology== {{medical citations needed|section|date=May 2018}}
===Use in traditional Chinese medicine===
The dried root of ''A. sinensis'' is commonly known as Chinese angelica ({{zh|t={{linktext|當歸}}|p=dāngguī|poj=tong-kui}}) and is widely used in [[Chinese traditional medicine]] for women's health, cardiovascular conditions, [[osteoarthrosis]], [[inflammation]], [[headache]], [[infections]], mild [[anemia]], [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]] and [[high blood pressure]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Angelica sinensis / Dong Quai|url=https://www.goldenlotusherbs.com/index.php?pageid=2&itemid=113|website=Golden Lotus Botanicals}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=May 2018}}<ref name=Medline /> The dong quai (當歸) means that a husband shall return to his wife, which is implicitly said to help women's sexual health.
''Dong quai'' is used for menopause vasomotor symptoms such as [[hot flashes]]. However, a randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial showed that ''dong quai'' was no more effective than placebo.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hirata|first1=Janie D|title=Does dong quai have estrogenic effects in postmenopausal women? A double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.|pmid=9418683|volume=68|issue=6|date=Dec 1997|journal=Fertil Steril|pages=981–6|doi=10.1016/s0015-0282(97)00397-x}}</ref>
Potential anti-osteoporotic effects of ''dong quai'' independent of any estrogen mechanism were evaluated in [[rat model]]s which showed that the extract of ''A. sinensis'' may prevent bone loss. However, more high quality human evidence is needed to confirm same anti-osteoporotic effects of ''dong quai'' in humans.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lim|first1=Dong Wook|title=Anti-Osteoporotic Effects of Angelica sinensis (Oliv.) Diels Extract on Ovariectomized Rats and Its Oral Toxicity in Rats.|pmid=25325255|doi=10.3390/nu6104362|volume=6|issue=10|date=Oct 2014|journal=Nutrients|pages=4362–72|pmc=4210922}}</ref>
''Dong quai'' contains a chemical compound called [[butylidenephthalide]] which has [[antispasmodic]] activity ''[[in vitro]]'' and might relieve [[dysmenorrhoea]] muscle cramps by relaxing the uterus muscle.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=WC|first1=Ko|title=A newly isolated antispasmodic--butylidenephthalide|pmid=7401411|volume=30|issue=1|date=Feb 1980|journal=Jpn J Pharmacol|pages=85–91}}</ref> However, this claim lacks evidence of effectiveness in human clinical trials.
In an animal study, ''Dong quai'' also induced hair growth via the inhibition of [[apoptosis]] signaling.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kim|first1=Mi Hye|last2=Choi|first2=You Yeon|last3=Cho|first3=Ik-Hyun|last4=Hong|first4=Jongki|last5=Kim|first5=Sung-Hoon|last6=Yang|first6=Woong Mo|title=Angelica sinensis Induces Hair Regrowth via the Inhibition of Apoptosis Signaling|journal=The American Journal of Chinese Medicine|date=January 2014|volume=42|issue=04|pages=1021–1034|doi=10.1142/S0192415X14500645}}</ref>
Overall, the [[U.S. National Library of Medicine]] states that more evidence is needed to rate the effectiveness of ''dong quai'' for most uses.<ref name=Medline />
===Adverse effects=== There is evidence that ''A. sinensis'' may affect the muscles of the uterus. Women who are pregnant or planning on becoming pregnant should not use ''A. sinensis'', because it may induce a miscarriage.<ref name=Medline /> Taking ''A. sinensis'' can cause skin to become extra sensitive to the sun, leading to a greater risk for skin cancer.<ref name=Medline/> One case of [[gynaecomastia]] has been reported following consumption of ''dong quai'' root powder pills.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Goh, S. Y. |author2=Loh, K. C. | title = Gynaecomastia and the Herbal Tonic ''Dong Quai'' | journal = Singapore Medical Journal | year = 2001 | volume = 42 | issue = 3 | pages = 115–116 | pmid = 11405562 }}</ref> Large and prolonged doses of the plant is not advised as it contains compounds that are considered carcinogenic.<ref name=Medline>{{ cite web | url = https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/natural/patient-dongquai.html | work = Medline Plus | publisher = NIH | title = Dong Quai }}</ref>
===Drug interactions=== ''A. sinensis'' may increase the anticoagulant effects of the drug [[warfarin]] (as it contains coumarins<ref>Simultaneous quantification of six main active constituents in Chinese Angelica by high-performance liquid chromatography with photodiode array detector https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3680850/</ref>) and consequently increase the risk of bleeding.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Page, R. L. |author2=Lawrence, J. D. | title = Potentiation of Warfarin by ''Dong Quai'' | journal = Pharmacotherapy | year = 1999 | volume = 19 | issue = 7 | pages = 870–876 | pmid = 10417036 | doi=10.1592/phco.19.10.870.31558}}</ref>
Due to the antiplatelet and [[anticoagulant]] effects of ''A. sinensis'', it should be taken with caution with herbs or supplements (such as [[ginkgo]], [[garlic]], and [[ginger]]) that may slow blood clotting to reduce the possible risk of bleeding and bruising.<ref name=Medline /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=HH|first1=Tsai|title=A review of potential harmful interactions between anticoagulant/antiplatelet agents and Chinese herbal medicines |pmid=23671711 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0064255 |volume=8 |issue=5 |year=2013 |journal=PLOS ONE|pages=e64255 |pmc=3650066}}</ref>
==Chemistry== The plant's chemical constituents include [[phytosterol]]s, [[polysaccharide]]s, ligustilit, b-butyl phtalit, cnidilit, isoenidilit, p-cymen, [[sodium ferulate|ferulate]], and [[flavonoid]]s.<ref>{{ cite journal |author1=Zhao, K. J. |author2=Dong, T. T. |author3=Tu, P. F. |author4=Song, Z. H. |author5=Lo, C. K. |author6=Tsim, K. W. | title = Molecular Genetic and Chemical Assessment of Radix Angelica (Danggui) in China | journal = Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry | year = 2003 | volume = 51 | issue = 9 | pages = 2576–2583 | pmid = 12696940 | doi = 10.1021/jf026178h }}</ref> When isolated from the plant, one of the chemicals, angelica polysaccharide sulfate, has ''[[in vitro]]'' antioxidant activity.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Jia, M. |author2=Yang, T. H. |author3=Yao, X. J. |author4=Meng, J. |author5=Meng, J. R. |author6=Mei, Q. B. |trans-title= Anti-oxidative effect of Angelica polysaccharide sulphate | journal = Zhong Yao Cai | year = 2007 | volume = 30 | issue = 2 | pages = 185–188 | pmid = 17571770 |script-title=zh:当归多聚糖硫酸盐的抗氧化作用 | language = Chinese }}</ref>
==See also== *''[[Angelica]]'' *[[Chinese herbology]] *''[[Scutellaria baicalensis]]'' (Baikal skullcap) *''[[Eleutherococcus senticosus]]'' or Siberian ginseng
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Kaiping|last2=Cao|first2=Peng|last3=Shui|first3=Weizhi|last4=Yang|first4=Qiuxiang|last5=Tang|first5=Zhuohong|last6=Zhang|first6=Yu|title=Angelica sinensis polysaccharide regulates glucose and lipid metabolism disorder in prediabetic and streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice through the elevation of glycogen levels and reduction of inflammatory factors|journal=Food & Function|date=19 Jan 2015|volume=6|issue=3|pages=902–909|doi=10.1039/c4fo00859f}}<!--|accessdate=2015--> *{{cite journal |author1=Jung, S. M. |author2=Schumacher, H. R. |author3=Kim, H. |author4=Kim, M. |author5=Lee, S. H. |author6=Pessler, F. | title = Reduction of Urate Crystal-Induced Inflammation by Root Extracts from Traditional Oriental Medicinal Plants: Elevation of Prostaglandin D<sub>2</sub> Levels | journal = [[Arthritis Research & Therapy]] | volume = 9 | issue = 4 | pages = R64 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17612394 | pmc = 2206389 | doi = 10.1186/ar2222 | url = http://arthritis-research.com/content/9/4/R64 }} - Considers anti-inflammatory properties of dried roots from the species ''Angelica sinensis ([[Dong Quai]])'', ''[[Acanthopanax senticosus]]'' (now known as ''[[Eleutherococcus senticosus]]'', or Siberian Ginseng), and ''[[Scutellaria baicalensis]] (Baikal Skullcap)''.
==External links== {{commonscat-inline}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041119180830/http://sun.ars-grin.gov:8080/npgspub/xsql/duke/plantdisp.xsql?taxon=87 ''Angelica sinensis'' List of Chemicals (Dr. Duke's Databases)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080905093932/http://www.omafra.gov.on.ca/english/crops/hort/herbs/cangel.htm Ontario Ministry of Agriculture and Food] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130731184658/http://libproject.hkbu.edu.hk/was40/detail?lang=en&channelid=1288&searchword=herb_id%3DD00117 Angelica Sinensis (Oliv.) Diels.] Medicinal Plant Images Database (School of Chinese Medicine, Hong Kong Baptist University) {{zh-hant}} *[http://libproject.hkbu.edu.hk/was40/outline?page=1&channelid=35734&searchword=%E7%95%B6%E6%AD%B8&sortfield=%2Bname_chi_sort&ispage=yes&trslc=50332398.1325071544.1 當歸, Dang Gui, Chinese Angelica]{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Chinese Medicine Specimen Database (School of Chinese Medicine, Hong Kong Baptist University) {{zh-hant}}
{{Taxonbar|from=Q2051387}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Arthur Aron | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|07|02}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | residence = [[Stony Brook, New York|Stony Brook]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | citizenship = [[United States]] | nationality = | fields = Psychology of [[interpersonal relationships]],
[[social psychology]] | workplaces = [[Stony Brook University|State University of New York at Stony Brook]] | patrons = | alma_mater = [[University of California at Berkeley]],
[[University of Toronto]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = A. J. Arrowood | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Self-expansion model]] of motivation in [[interpersonal relationship]]s | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|www.psychology.stonybrook.edu/aronlab-/}} | footnotes = | spouse = Elaine Aron | children = | death_cause = | education = BA, MA ([[University of California at Berkeley]]),
PhD ([[University of Toronto]]) | partner = }} '''Arthur Aron''' (born July 2, 1945) is a professor of [[psychology]] at the [[Stony Brook University|State University of New York at Stony Brook]]. He is best known for his work on [[intimacy]] in [[interpersonal relationship]]s, and development of the [[self-expansion model]] of motivation in close relationships. == Early life and education == Arthur Aron received a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[psychology]] and [[philosophy]] in 1967 and a [[master's degree]] in [[social psychology]] in 1968, both from the [[University of California at Berkeley]]. He earned a PhD in [[social psychology]] from the [[University of Toronto]] in 1970.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ==Career== Aron's work focuses on the role, creation, and maintenance of friendship and intimacy in interpersonal relationships. He developed the [[self-expansion model]] of close relationships; it posits that one of the motivations humans have for forming close relationships is self-expansion, i.e., "expansion of the [[self]]", or [[personal growth]] and development. ==Personal life== Aron is [[marriage in the United States|married]] to psychologist [[Elaine Aron]].[[WebMD]], [http://www.webmd.com/elaine-n-aron Elaine N. Aron, PhD biography] == References == {{Reflist}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.psychology.stonybrook.edu/aronlab-/ |title=Arthur Aron's CV |author= |date=May 31, 2011 |website=[[Stony Brook University|State University of New York at Stony Brook]] |publisher= |accessdate=January 11, 2015}} * {{cite journal |last=Sprecher |first=Susan |date=March 1988 |title=Love and the Expansion of Self: Understanding Attraction and Satisfaction by Arthur Aron; Elaine Aron|jstor=2070652 |journal=[[Contemporary Sociology]] |publisher=[[American Sociological Association]] |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=268–269 |doi=10.2307/2070652 }} * {{cite news |last=Catron |first=Mandy Len |date=January 9, 2015 |title=To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/11/fashion/modern-love-to-fall-in-love-with-anyone-do-this.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |location=[[New York City]] |accessdate=January 11, 2015}} * {{cite news |last=Jones |first=Daniel |date=January 9, 2015 |title=No. 37: Big Wedding or Small? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/11/fashion/no-37-big-wedding-or-small.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |location=[[New York City]] |accessdate=January 11, 2015}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aron, Arthur}} [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:Stony Brook University faculty]] [[Category:Living people]]

page.title: Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children

revision.text:
{{Infobox laboratory |name= Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children |logo= [[File:Children-of-the-90s-logo-2012.png]] |established= 1991 |director= [[George Davey Smith]] |city= [[Bristol]]
|operating_agency = [[University of Bristol]]
|website = http://childrenofthe90s.ac.uk/ }} The '''Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children''' ('''ALSPAC'''), also known as '''Children of the 90s''' and formerly the '''Avon Longitudinal Study of Pregnancy and Childhood''', is a [[cohort study]] of children born in the former county of [[Avon (county)|Avon]], [[England]] during 1991 and 1992.<ref name= "alspac website">http://www.bristol.ac.uk/alspac/ ALSPAC website, accessed 15 October 2014</ref> It is used by researchers in health, education and other social science disciplines.
The study is hosted at the [[University of Bristol]] and was initially led by [[Jean Golding]] and is now directed by [[George Davey Smith]].<ref>http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/Achievements-and-Impact/Initiatives/UK-biomedical-science/ALSPAC/index.htm [[Wellcome Trust]] page on ALSPAC, accessed 24 February 2010</ref> The initial recruits were 15,247 pregnant women with estimated dates of delivery between April 1991 and December 1992. Since then the fathers, siblings and children of the participants have also begun to be studied.<ref name= "alspac website" />
It is one of a family of similar studies that were set up at around the same time in six countries across Europe, known as the European Longitudinal Study of Pregnancy and Childhood (ELSPAC). ELSPAC included studies in [[Czechoslovakia]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elspac.cz/index-en.php?pg=about |title=About the ELSPAC study |publisher=ELSPAC |accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref> and the [[Isle of Man]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/social-community-medicine/projects/isleofmanstudy/ |title=ELSPAC in the Isle of Man |publisher=University of Bristol |accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref> in addition to ALSPAC.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite journal|last=Pearson|first=Helen|title=Children of the 90s: Coming of age|journal=Nature|date=12 April 2012|volume=484|issue=7393|pages=155–158|doi=10.1038/484155a|pmid=22498607}} * {{cite journal|last=Frood|first=Arran|title=Profile: Children of the 90s comes of age|journal=The Lancet|date=26 May 2012|volume=379|issue=9830|pages=1938|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60843-5}} * {{cite journal|last=Boyd|first=A.|author2=Golding, J.|author3=Macleod, J.|author4=Lawlor, D. A.|author5=Fraser, A.|author6=Henderson, J.|author7=Molloy, L.|author8=Ness, A.|author9=Ring, S.|author10= Davey Smith, G.|title=Cohort Profile: The 'Children of the 90s'--the index offspring of the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|date=16 April 2012|pages=1–17|doi=10.1093/ije/dys064|volume=42|pmid=22507743|pmc=3600618}} * {{cite journal|last1=Fraser|first1=A.|last2=Macdonald-Wallis|first2=C.|last3= Tilling|first3=K.|last4= Boyd|first4= A.|last5= Golding|first5= J.|last6= Davey Smith|first6= G.|last7= Henderson|first7= J.|last8= Macleod|first8= J.|last9= Molloy|first9= L.|last10= Ness|first10= A.|last11= Ring|first11= S.|last12= Nelson|first12= S. M.|last13= Lawlor|first13= D. A.|title=Cohort Profile: The Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children: ALSPAC mothers cohort|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|date=16 April 2012|doi=10.1093/ije/dys066|volume=42|pages=97–110}} * {{cite book|last=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group|authorlink=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group|title=History of the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC), c.1980–2000|year=2012|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|isbn=978 090223 8787|editor1=C Overy |editor2=L A Reynolds |editor3=E M Tansey |url=http://www.history.qmul.ac.uk/research/modbiomed/Publications/wit_vols/76843.pdf}}
