revision.text:
{{broader|Mental disorder}} A [[mental disorder]] is "''a clinically significant behavioral or psychological syndrome or psychological pattern that occurs in an individual and that is associated with present disability or with a significantly increased risk of suffering, death, pain, disability, or an important loss of freedom.''"<ref>{{ cite book |publisher= American Psychiatric Association (APA) |date= 2000 |title= Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR) |edition= 4th, Text Revision |location= Washington, DC |chapter= |last1= |first1= |pages= }}</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=August 2018}}
The '''causes of mental disorders''' are regarded as complex and varying depending on the particular disorder and the individual. Although the causes of most mental disorders are not fully understood, researchers have identified a variety of biological, psychological, and environmental factors that can contribute to the development or progression of mental disorders.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S2215-0366(18)30057-9 |pmid=29773478 |title=Preventive strategies for mental health |journal=The Lancet Psychiatry |volume=5 |issue=7 |pages=591 |year=2018 |last1=Arango |first1=Celso |last2=Díaz-Caneja |first2=Covadonga M |last3=McGorry |first3=Patrick D |last4=Rapoport |first4=Judith |last5=Sommer |first5=Iris E |last6=Vorstman |first6=Jacob A |last7=McDaid |first7=David |last8=Marín |first8=Oscar |last9=Serrano-Drozdowskyj |first9=Elena |last10=Freedman |first10=Robert |last11=Carpenter |first11=William }}</ref> Most mental disorders are a result of a combination of several different factors rather than just a single factor.
==Research results== Risk factors for mental illness include, psychological trauma, adverse childhood environments, genetic predisposition<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/bjp.bp.111.104984 |title=Risk of psychopathology in adolescent offspring of mothers with psychopathology and recurrent depression |year=2012 |last1=Sellers |first1=R. |last2=Collishaw |first2=S |last3=Rice |first3=F |last4=Thapar |first4=AK |last5=Potter |first5=R |last6=Mars |first6=B |last7=Harold |first7=GT |last8=Smith |first8=DJ |last9=Owen |first9=MJ |display-authors= 2 |journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=202 |issue=2 |pages=108–14 |pmid=23060622 |last10=Craddock |first10=N. |last11=Thapar |first11=A.}}</ref><ref name="pmid24206921">{{cite journal |last1=Hancock |first1=KJ |last2=Mitrou |first2=F |last3=Shipley |first3=M |last4=Lawrence |first4=D |last5=Zubrick |first5=SR |display-authors= 2 |title=A three generation study of the mental health relationships between grandparents, parents and children |journal=BMC Psychiatry |volume=13 |pages=299 |year=2013 |pmid=24206921 |pmc=3829660 |doi=10.1186/1471-244X-13-299 }}</ref><ref name="academia.edu">{{cite journal |url= https://www.academia.edu/934804/Parents_with_Mental_Illness_They_Cycle_of_Intergenerational_Mental_Illness |title= Parents with mental Illness: The cycle of intergenerational mental illness |first= M |last= Boursnell |date= 2011 |journal= Children Australia |volume= 36 |issue= 1 |pages= 23–32 |doi= |pmid= |via= Academia.edu}}</ref> and personality traits.<ref name="NeuroticismMA">{{cite journal |last1=Jeronimus |first1=BF |last2=Kotov |first2=R |last3=Riese |first3=H |last4=Ormel |first4=J |display-authors= 2 |title=Neuroticism's prospective association with mental disorders halves after adjustment for baseline symptoms and psychiatric history, but the adjusted association hardly decays with time: A meta-analysis on 59 longitudinal/prospective studies with 443 313 participants |journal=Psychological Medicine |volume= 46|issue= 14|pages=1–24 |year=2016 |pmid=27523506 |doi=10.1017/S0033291716001653 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ormel |first1=J |last2=Jeronimus |first2=BF |last3=Kotov |first3=R |last4=Riese |first4=H |last5=Bos |first5=EH |last6=Hankin |first6=B |last7=Rosmalen |first7=JGM |last8=Oldehinkel |first8=AJ |display-authors= 2 |title=Neuroticism and common mental disorders: Meaning and utility of a complex relationship |journal=Clinical Psychology Review |volume=33 |issue=5 |pages=686–97 |year=2013 |pmid=23702592 |pmc=4382368 |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2013.04.003 }}</ref> Correlations of mental disorders with drug use include almost all psychoactive substances, e.g., [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]],<ref name="rcpsych.ac.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/mentalhealthinfo/problems/alcoholanddrugs/cannabis.aspx |title=Cannabis and mental health |publisher=Rcpsych.ac.uk |date= |accessdate= 23 April 2013}}</ref> [[Long-term effects of alcohol#Mental health effects|alcohol]]<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fergusson |first1=DM |last2=Boden |first2=JM |last3=Horwood |first3=LJ |title=Tests of causal links between alcohol abuse or dependence and major depression |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=66 |issue=3 |pages=260–6 |year=2009 |pmid=19255375 |doi=10.1001/archgenpsychiatry.2008.543 }}</ref> and [[caffeine]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/apt.11.6.432 |title=Neuropsychiatric effects of caffeine |year=2005 |last1=Winston |first1=AP |journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=432–9 }}</ref>
Particular mental illnesses have particular risk factors, for instance including unequal parental treatment, adverse life events and drug use in [[depression (mood)|depression]],<ref name="rcpsych.ac.uk"/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1741-3737.2010.00703.x |title=Mothers' Differentiation and depressive symptoms among adult children |year=2010 |last1=Pillemer |first1=K |last2=Suitor |first2=JJ |last3=Pardo |first3=S |last4=Henderson |first4=C, Jr |display-authors= 2 |journal=Journal of Marriage and Family |volume=72 |issue=2 |pages=333–45 |pmid=20607119 |pmc=2894713}}</ref> migration and discrimination, childhood trauma, bereavement or separation in families, and cannabis use in [[schizophrenia]] and [[psychosis]],<ref name="rcpsych.ac.uk"/><ref name="schizophreniacommission.org.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.schizophreniacommission.org.uk/the-report/ |title=The Report |publisher=The Schizophrenia Commission |date= 13 November 2012 |accessdate= 23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405104051/http://www.schizophreniacommission.org.uk/the-report/ |archivedate= 5 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> and parenting factors, child abuse,<ref name="National Academies Press">{{cite book |chapterurl=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=12480&page=530 |chapter= Table E-4 Risk Factors for Anxiety |page=530 |editor1-first= Mary Ellen |editor1-last=O'Connell |editor2-first=Thomas |editor2-last=Boat |editor3-first=Kenneth E. |editor3-last=Warner |publisher=National Academies Press |title=Prevention of Mental Disorders, Substance Abuse, and Problem Behaviors: A Developmental Perspective |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-309-12674-8}}</ref> family history (e.g. of anxiety), and temperament and attitudes (e.g. pessimism) in [[anxiety]].<ref name="Bienvenu Ginsburg 2007">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09540260701797837 |title=Prevention of anxiety disorders |year=2007 |last1=Bienvenu |first1=OJ |last2=Ginsburg |first2=GS |journal=[[International Review of Psychiatry]] |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=647–54 |pmid=18092242}}</ref> Many psychiatric disorders include problems with [[impulse control disorder|impulse and other emotional control]].
In February 2013 a study found common genetic links between five major psychiatric disorders: [[autism]], [[ADHD]], [[bipolar disorder]], [[major depressive disorder]], and [[schizophrenia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Five Very Different and Major Psych Disorders Have Shared Genetics|first=Catherine |last= Griffin|url=http://www.scienceworldreport.com/articles/5266/20130228/five-very-different-major-psych-disorders-shared-genetics.htm|work=Science World Report|date=28 February 2013|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref> Abnormal functioning of [[neurotransmitter]] systems has been implicated{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} in several mental disorders, including serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine and glutamate systems. Differences have also been found in the size or activity of certain brain regions in some cases. Psychological mechanisms have also been implicated, such as [[cognitive]] (e.g. [[reasoning]]) biases, [[emotional]] influences, [[Personality psychology|personality]] dynamics, [[temperament]] and [[Coping (psychology)|coping]] style. Studies have indicated{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} that variation in [[genes]] can play an important role in the development of mental disorders, although the reliable identification of connections between specific genes and specific categories of disorder has proven more difficult. Environmental events surrounding [[pregnancy]] and [[birth]] have also been implicated{{Citation needed|date=October 2016}}. [[Traumatic brain injury]] may increase the risk of developing certain mental disorders. There have been some tentative inconsistent links found to certain viral infections, to substance misuse, and to general physical health.
Social influences have been found to be important{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}, including [[abuse]], [[neglect]], [[bullying]], [[social stress]], [[Traumatic event (psychological)|traumatic events]] and other negative or overwhelming life experiences. The specific risks and pathways to particular disorders are less clear, however. Aspects of the wider community have also been implicated,{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} including [[employment]] problems, [[socioeconomic]] [[Economic inequality|inequality]], lack of social cohesion, problems linked to [[Human migration|migration]], and features of particular [[societies]] and [[cultures]].
==Theories==
===General theories=== There are a number of [[theories]] or [[scientific modelling|models]] seeking to explain the causes ([[etiology]]) of [[mental disorder]]s. These theories may differ in regards to how they explain the cause of the disorder, how they treat the disorder, and their basic [[classification of mental disorders]]. There may also be differences in [[philosophy of mind]] regarding whether, or how, the [[mind]] is considered separately from the [[brain]].
During most of the 20th century, mental illness was believed to be caused by problematic relationships between children and their parents. This view was held well into the late 1990s, in which people still believed this child-parent relationship was a large determinant of severe mental illness, such as depression and schizophrenia. Today,{{When|date=June 2014}} the belief is held that the child-parent relationship is of small importance in terms of causing mental illness compared to biological and genetic factors{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}. So, the perceived causes of mental illness have changed over time and will most likely continue to alter while more research is done in this area.<ref name="Link Phelan 1999">{{cite journal |last1=Link |first1=BG |last2=Phelan |first2=JC |last3=Bresnahan |first3=M |last4=Stueve |first4=A |last5=Pescosolido |first5=BA |display-authors= 2 |title=Public conceptions of mental illness: Labels, causes, dangerousness, and social distance |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=89 |issue=9 |pages=1328–33 |year=1999 |pmid=10474548 |pmc=1508784 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.89.9.1328 }}</ref>
Outside the West, community approaches remain a focus.<ref name="mentalhealth.freeuk.com">{{cite journal |url= http://www.mentalhealth.freeuk.com/pjns.pdf |title= Explanatory models for mental illness: Limitations and dangers in a global context |last1= Thomas |first1= P |last2= Bracken |first2= P |last3= Yasmeen |first3= S |journal= Pak J Neurol Sci |date= 2007 |volume= 2 |issue= 3 |pages= 176–81 |via= www.mentalhealth.freeuk.com |pmid= |doi= }}</ref>
===Medical or biomedical model=== An overall distinction is also commonly made between a "medical model" (also known as a biomedical or disease model) and a "social model" (also known as an empowerment or recovery model) of mental disorder and [[disability]], with the former focusing on hypothesized disease processes and symptoms, and the latter focusing on hypothesized [[social constructionism]] and social contexts.<ref name="Rogers&Pilgram05">{{cite book |author1=Pilgrim, David |author2=Rogers, Anne |title=A sociology of mental health and illness |publisher=Open University Press |location=[[Milton Keynes]] |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-335-21583-6}}</ref>
[[Biological psychiatry]] has tended to follow a [[biomedical]] model focused on organic or "hardware" pathology of the brain,<ref name="Ghaemi 2006"/> where many mental disorders are conceptualized as disorders of brain circuits likely caused by developmental processes shaped by a complex interplay of genetics and experience.<ref name=Insel>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1001/jama.2010.555 | last1 = Insel | first1 = T.R. | last2 = Wang | first2 = P.S. | year = 2010 | title = Rethinking mental illness | url = | journal = JAMA | volume = 303 | issue = 19| pages = 1970–1971 | pmid = 20483974 }}</ref>
===Biopsychosocial model=== The primary model of contemporary mainstream Western psychiatry is the [[biopsychosocial model]] (BPS), which merges biological, psychological and social factors.<ref name= "Ghaemi 2006"/> For instance one view is that genetics accounts for 40% of a person's susceptibility to mental disorders while psychological and environmental factors account for the other 60%.<ref name="minddisorders.com">{{cite web |last= Frey |first= Rebecca J. |url= http://www.minddisorders.com/Flu-Inv/Genetic-factors-and-mental-disorders.html#b |title= Genetic factors and mental disorders |website= www.minddisorders.com |date= |access-date= |publisher= Advameg}}</ref>{{Better source|date=November 2017}} It may be commonly neglected or misapplied in practice due to being too broad or relativistic, however.
The most common view <ref>{{cite book|first1= Rangaswamy Srinivasa |last1= Murthy |display-authors= etal |title=The World Health Report 2001: Mental Health, New Understanding, New Hope|orig-year=2001 |date= 2002 |publisher=World Health Organization|location=Geneva|edition= Reprint|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GQEdA-VFSIgC&pg=PR9&dq=mental+health+comes+from+genetics#v=onepage&q=genetics&f=false |isbn= 9789241562010}}</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=November 2017}} is that disorders tend to result from genetic dispositions and environmental stressors, combining to cause patterns of distress or dysfunction or, more sharply, trigger disorders ([[Diathesis-stress model]]). A practical mixture of models may often be used to explain particular issues and disorders,<ref name="Ghaemi 2006">{{cite journal |last=Ghaemi |first= SN |title= Paradigms of psychiatry: Eclecticism and its discontents |journal=Current Opinion in Psychiatry |volume=19 |issue=6 |pages=619–24 |date=November 2006 |pmid=17012942 |doi= 10.1097/01.yco.0000245751.98749.52 |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/547497_print}}</ref> although there may be difficulty defining boundaries for indistinct psychiatric [[syndromes]].<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=10588394 |year=1999 |author1=Kendler |first1=K. S |title=Setting boundaries for psychiatric disorders |journal=The American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=156 |issue=12 |pages=1845–8 |doi=10.1176/ajp.156.12.1845 |doi-broken-date=2018-08-15 }}</ref>
===Psychoanalytic theories=== [[Psychoanalytic]] theories focus on unresolved internal and relational conflicts. These theories have been posited as overall explanations of mental disorder, although today most psychoanalytic groups are said to adhere to the biopsychosocial model and to accept an eclectic mix of subtypes of psychoanalysis.<ref name="Ghaemi 2006"/> The psychoanalytic theory was originated by [[Sigmund Freud]]. This theory focuses on the impact of unconscious forces on human behavior. According to Freud, the personality is made up of three parts: the [[Id, ego and super-ego|id]], [[Id, ego and super-ego#Ego|ego]], and [[superego]]. The id operates under the [[pleasure principle (psychology)|pleasure principle]], the ego operates under the [[reality principle]], and the superego is the "conscience" and incorporates what is and is not socially acceptable into a person's value system. Also, according to the psychoanalytic theory, there are five stages of psycho-sexual development that everyone goes through: the [[oral stage]], [[anal stage]], [[phallic stage]], [[latency stage]], and [[genital stage]]. Mental disorders can be caused by an individual receiving too little or too much gratification in one of the psycho-sexual developmental stages. When this happens, the individual is said to be [[Fixation (psychology)|fixated]] in that developmental stage.<ref name="Segrist 2009">{{cite journal|last1=Segrist|first1=Dan J.|title=What's Going on in Your Professor's Head? Demonstrating the Id, Ego, and Superego|journal=Teaching of Psychology|volume=36| issue=1|year=2009|pages=51–54| doi=10.1080/00986280802529285}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Westen D | year = 1998 | title = The scientific legacy of Sigmund Freud: Toward a psychodynamically informed psychological science | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 124 | issue = 3| pages = 333–371 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.124.3.333| citeseerx = 10.1.1.590.4857 }}</ref>
===Attachment theory=== [[Attachment theory]] is a kind of evolutionary-psychological approach sometimes applied in the context for mental disorders, which focuses on the role of early caregiver-child relationships, responses to danger, and the search for a satisfying reproductive relationship in adulthood.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Crittenden PM |title=Attachment, information processing, and psychiatric disorder |journal=World Psychiatry |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=72–75 | date=June 2002 | pmid=16946856 |pmc=1525137}}</ref> According to this theory, the more secure a child's attachment is to a nurturing adult, the more likely that child will maintain healthy relationships with others in their life. As found by the [[Strange Experiment|Strange Situation experiment]] run by [[Mary Ainsworth]] based on the formulations of [[John Bowlby]], there are four main patterns of attachment: [[secure attachment]], [[Attachment styles|avoidant attachment]], [[disorganized attachment]] and [[ambivalent attachment]]. These attachment patterns are found cross-culturally.<ref>Vondra, J. I., & Barnett, D. (1999). A typical attachment in infancy and early childhood among children at developmental risk. Monographs of the Society for Research in Child Development, 64 (3, Serial No. 258).</ref> Later research found a fourth pattern of attachment known as [[Disorganized attachment|disorganized disoriented attachment]]. Secure attachments reflect trust in the child-caretaker relationship while insecure attachment reflects mistrust. The security of attachment in a child affects the child's emotional, cognitive, and social competence later in life.<ref>{{cite web |first1=Gregory |last1=Lowder |first2=James |last2=Hansell |first3=Nancy |last3=McWilliams |year= |title=The Enduring Significance of Psychoanalytic Theory and Practice |url=http://www.apadivisions.org/division-39/leadership/apsaa/significance.pdf }}</ref>
===Evolutionary psychology=== [[Evolutionary psychology]] (or more specifically evolutionary psychopathology or psychiatry) has also been proposed as an overall theory, positing that many mental disorders involve the dysfunctional operation of [[mental module]]s adapted to [[ancestral]] physical or social environments but not necessarily to modern ones.<ref>{{cite book |last=Baron-Cohen |first= Simon |title=The Maladapted Mind: Classic Readings in Evolutionary Psychopathology |publisher=Psychology Press |location=East Sussex |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-86377-460-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Brüne |first= M |title=Toward an integration of interpersonal and biological processes: Evolutionary psychiatry as an empirically testable framework for psychiatric research |journal=Psychiatry |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=48–57 |year=2002 |pmid=11980046 |doi=10.1521/psyc.65.1.48.19759}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Nesse |first= RM |title=Evolutionary biology: A basic science for psychiatry |journal=World Psychiatry |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=7–9 |date=February 2002 |pmid=16946805 |pmc=1489830}}</ref> Other theories suggest that mental illness could have evolutionary advantages for the species, including in enhancing creativity.<ref name="Andreasen 1987">{{cite journal |doi=10.1176/ajp.144.10.1288 |pmid=3499088 |title=Creativity and mental illness: Prevalence rates in writers and their first-degree relatives |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=144 |issue=10 |pages=1288–92 |year=1987 |author1=Andreasen |first1=N. C }}</ref> Some related behavioral abnormalities have been found in non-human [[great apes]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2006.09.002 |pmid=17141312 |title=Psychopathology in great apes: Concepts, treatment options and possible homologies to human psychiatric disorders |journal=Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews |volume=30 |issue=8 |pages=1246–59 |year=2006 |last1=Brune |first1=M |last2=Brunecohrs |first2=U |last3=McGrew |first3=W |last4=Preuschoft |first4=S }}</ref> Evolutionary psychology applies Darwinian principles to human behavior by saying that human minds are products of natural selection and have specific functions. Humans strive to carry on their genetic legacy through their offspring. This theory identifies the environment as having a great effect on a person's mental development.<ref>{{cite book |last= Downes |first= S. |chapter= Evolutionary Psychology |date= 21 May 2014 |title= Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |url= http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/evolutionary-psychology/ |editor-last= Aalta |editor-first= Edward N. |archive-url= https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2017/entries/evolutionary-psychology/ |archive-date= 21 December 2017 |deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Factors affecting choice of models and theories=== Psychiatrists may favour biomedical models because they believe such models make their discipline seem more esteemed.<ref name="Angermeyer 2011">{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/bjp.bp.110.085563 |pmid=22045945 |title=Biogenetic explanations and public acceptance of mental illness: Systematic review of population studies |journal=British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=199 |issue=5 |pages=367–72 |year=2018 |last1=Angermeyer |first1=Matthias C |last2=Holzinger |first2=Anita |last3=Carta |first3=Mauro G |last4=Schomerus |first4=Georg }}</ref> Similarly, families of mentally ill people tend to favour biomedical models because to do so gives less self-blame.<ref>{{citation |mode=cs1 |last= Martinez |first= Margaret A. |url= http://www.yale.edu/psychdus/Senior_Essays_files/f.pdf |title= The Blame Game: Lay casual theories and familiarity with mental illness |date= 19 April 2010 |archive-date= 22 February 2014 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140222191356/http://www.yale.edu/psychdus/Senior_Essays_files/f.pdf |deadurl= yes |page= |type= Senior Thesis in Psychology}}</ref>{{Medical citation needed|date=November 2017}} If patients are seen by a more ethnically similar doctor, they are more likely to adopt a non-biomedical model.<ref name="Ghane 2010">{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00127-009-0053-1 |pmid=19381425 |pmc=2820666 |title=Assessment of explanatory models of mental illness: Effects of patient and interviewer characteristics |journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=175–82 |year=2009 |last1=Ghane |first1=Samrad |last2=Kolk |first2=Annemarie M |last3=Emmelkamp |first3=Paul M. G }}</ref>
==Biological factors== Biological factors consist of anything physical that can cause adverse effects on a person's mental health. This includes genetics, prenatal damage, infections, exposure to toxins, brain defects or injuries, and substance abuse.<ref name="webmd.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.webmd.com/anxiety-panic/mental-health-causes-mental-illness |title= Causes of Mental Illness |date= |access-date= |work= WebMD}}</ref>{{Better source|date=November 2017}} Many professionals believe that the sole cause of mental disorders is based upon the biology of the brain and the nervous system.<ref name="netplaces.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.netplaces.com/psychology/disorders-when-thinking-and-emotionality-go-awry/causes-of-mental-disorders.htm |title= Causes of Mental Disorders |last= Cherry |first= Kendra |archive-date= 12 May 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150512134316/http://www.netplaces.com/psychology/disorders-when-thinking-and-emotionality-go-awry/causes-of-mental-disorders.htm |deadurl= yes |website= www.netplaces.com |publisher= About.com}}</ref>{{Unreliable medical source|date=November 2017}}
[[Mind (charity)|''Mind'']] mentions genetic factors, long-term physical health conditions, and head injuries or epilepsy (affecting behaviour and mood) as factors that may possibly trigger an episode of mental illness.<ref name="mind.org.uk">{{cite web |url= http://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/mental-health-problems-(general)/what-causes-mental-health-problems/#.U1ItYeZdUz4 |title= What causes mental health problems? |deadurl= yes |archive-date= 30 May 2014 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140330190323/http://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/mental-health-problems-(general)/what-causes-mental-health-problems/#.WgsHinZryM8 |website= www.mind.org.uk |publisher= [[Mind (charity)|Mind]]}}</ref>
===Genetics===
Family-linkage and [[twin studies]] have indicated that genetic factors often play an important role in the development of mental disorders. The reliable identification of specific genetic susceptibility to particular disorders, through [[genetic linkage|linkage]] or [[genetic association|association studies]], has proven difficult.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Insel |first1= TR |last2= Collins |first2= FS |title=Psychiatry in the genomics era |journal=Am J Psychiatry |volume=160 |issue=4 |pages=616–20 |date=April 2003 |pmid=12668345 |url= http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/full/160/4/616 |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.160.4.616}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bearden |first1=CE |last2= Reus |first2= VI |last3= Freimer |first3=NB |title=Why genetic investigation of psychiatric disorders is so difficult |journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=280–6 |date=June 2004 |pmid=15172671 |doi= 10.1016/j.gde.2004.04.005}}</ref> This has been reported to be likely due to the complexity of interactions between genes, environmental events, and early development<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Kas |first1= MJ |last2= Fernandes |first2= C |last3= Schalkwyk |first3= LC |last4= Collier |first4= DA |display-authors= 2 |title=Genetics of behavioural domains across the neuropsychiatric spectrum: Of mice and men |journal=Mol Psychiatry |volume=12 |issue=4 |pages=324–30 |date=April 2007 |pmid=17389901 |doi=10.1038/sj.mp.4001979}}</ref> or to the need for new research strategies.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Burmeister |first= M | year = 2006 | title = Genetics of psychiatric disorders: A primer | doi = 10.1176/foc.4.3.317 | journal = Focus | volume = 4 | issue = 3| page = 317 |doi-broken-date= 2018-08-15 |url=https://focus.psychiatryonline.org/doi/abs/10.1176/foc.4.3.317 }}</ref> The [[heritability]] of behavioral traits associated with mental disorder may be greater in permissive than in restrictive environments, and susceptibility genes probably work through both "within-the-skin" (physiological) pathways and "outside-the-skin" (behavioral and social) pathways.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kendler |first1=KS |title=Twin studies of psychiatric illness |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=58 |issue=11 |pages=1005–14 |year=2001 |pmid=11695946 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.58.11.1005 }}</ref> Investigations increasingly focus on links between genes and endophenotypes—more specific traits (including neurophysiological, biochemical, endocrinological, neuroanatomical, cognitive, or neuropsychological)—rather than disease categories.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bearden |first1= CE |last2= Freimer |first2= NB |title=Endophenotypes for psychiatric disorders: Ready for primetime? |journal=Trends Genet. |volume=22 |issue=6 |pages=306–13 |date=June 2006 |pmid=16697071 |doi=10.1016/j.tig.2006.04.004 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1= Glahn |first1= DC |last2= Thompson |first2= PM |last3= Blangero |first3= J |date=June 2007 |journal=[[Hum Brain Mapp]] |volume=28 |issue=6 |pages=488–501 |doi=10.1002/hbm.20401 |pmid= 17440953 |title=Neuroimaging endophenotypes: Strategies for finding genes influencing brain structure and function|url=http://www.soph.uab.edu/Statgenetics/Club_ssg/WPrucka_07_2.pdf |citeseerx= 10.1.1.582.7919 }}</ref> With regard to a prominent mental disorder, [[schizophrenia]], for a long time consensus among scientists was that certain [[alleles]] (forms of genes) were responsible for schizophrenia, but some research has indicated only multiple, rare mutations thought to alter neurodevelopmental pathways that can ultimately contribute to schizophrenia; virtually every rare structural mutation was different in each individual.<ref name=Genetics>{{cite web|last=Walsh|first=Tom|title=Rare Structural Variants Disrupt Multiple Genes in Neurodevelopmental Pathways in Schizophrenia|url=http://www.uwpsychiatry.org/Docs/News/McClellan_Science_Paper.pdf|publisher=Science|accessdate=11 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722054257/http://www.uwpsychiatry.org/Docs/News/McClellan_Science_Paper.pdf|archivedate=22 July 2011|df=}}</ref>
Research has shown that many conditions are polygenic meaning there are multiple defective genes rather than only one that are responsible for a disorder.<ref name="webmd.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}} [[Schizophrenia]] and [[Alzheimer's]] are both examples of hereditary mental disorders.<ref name="minddisorders.com"/>
The increasing understanding of [[neuroplasticity|brain plasticity (neuroplasticity)]] raises questions of whether some brain differences may be caused by mental illnesses, rather than pre-existing and causing them.
===Prenatal damage=== Any damage that occurs to a fetus while still in its mother's womb is considered prenatal damage. If the pregnant mother uses drugs or alcohol or is exposed to illnesses or infections then mental disorders can develop in the fetus. According to research, certain conditions, such as [[autism]] result from a disruption of early fetal brain progression.<ref name="webmd.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}}
Environmental events surrounding [[pregnancy]] and [[birth]] have been linked to an increased development of mental illness in the [[offspring]]. This includes maternal exposure to serious psychological [[stress (medicine)|stress]] or [[psychological trauma|trauma]], conditions of famine, [[obstetric]] birth complications, infections, and [[gestational]] exposure to [[alcohol]] or [[cocaine]]. Such factors have been hypothesized to affect specific areas of neurodevelopment within the general developmental context and to restrict [[neuroplasticity]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fumagalli |first1= F |last2= Molteni |first2= R |last3= Racagni |first3= G |last4= Riva |first4= MA |display-authors= 2 |title=Stress during development: Impact on neuroplasticity and relevance to psychopathology |journal=Prog. Neurobiol. |volume=81 |issue=4 |pages=197–217 |date=March 2007 |pmid=17350153 |doi=10.1016/j.pneurobio.2007.01.002}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1= Feldman |first1= P. |last2= Papalia |first2= D. |date= 2012 |title= Experience Human Development |edition= 12th |location= New York, NY |publisher= McGraw-Hill |page= 108 |isbn=978-0078035142}}</ref>
===Infection, disease and toxins=== A number of psychiatric disorders have often been tentatively linked with microbial pathogens, particularly viruses; however while there have been some suggestions of links from animal studies, and some inconsistent evidence for infectious and immune mechanisms (including prenatally) in some human disorders, infectious disease models in psychiatry are reported to have not yet shown significant promise except in isolated cases.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pearce |first1=BD |title=Modeling the role of infections in the etiology of mental illness |journal=Clinical Neuroscience Research |volume=3 |issue=4–5 |year=2003 |pages=271–82 |doi=10.1016/S1566-2772(03)00098-7 }}</ref>
There have been some inconsistent findings of links between infection by the parasite [[Toxoplasma gondii]] and human mental disorders such as schizophrenia, with the direction of causality unclear.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1471-244X-4-32 |pmid=15491496 |pmc=526777 |title=Toxoplasma and coxiella infection and psychiatric morbidity: A retrospective cohort analysis |journal=BMC Psychiatry |volume=4 |pages=32 |year=2004 |last1=Thomas |first1=Hollie V |last2=Thomas |first2=Daniel Rh |last3=Salmon |first3=Roland L |last4=Lewis |first4=Glyn |last5=Smith |first5=Andy P }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1471-2334-6-178 |pmid=17178002 |pmc=1764421 |title=Seroepidemiology of Toxoplasma gondiiinfection in psychiatric inpatients in a northern Mexican city |journal=BMC Infectious Diseases |volume=6 |pages=178 |year=2006 |last1=Alvarado-Esquivel |first1=Cosme |last2=Alanis-Quiñones |first2=Olga-Patricia |last3=Arreola-Valenzuela |first3=Miguel-Ángel |last4=Rodríguez-Briones |first4=Alfredo |last5=Piedra-Nevarez |first5=Luis-Jorge |last6=Duran-Morales |first6=Ehecatl |last7=Estrada-Martínez |first7=Sergio |last8=Martínez-García |first8=Sergio-Arturo |last9=Liesenfeld |first9=Oliver }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1= Yolken |first1= RH |last2= Torrey |first2= EF |title=Viruses, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder |journal=Clin Microbiol Rev |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=131–45 |date=1 January 1995|pmid=7704891 |pmc=172852 |url=http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7704891 }}</ref> A number of diseases of the white matter can cause symptoms of mental disorder.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Walterfang |first1= M |last2=Wood |first2= SJ |last3=Velakoulis |first3= D |last4=Copolov |first4= D |last5= Pantelis |first5= C |display-authors= 2 |title=Diseases of white matter and schizophrenia-like psychosis |journal=Aust N Z J Psychiatry. |volume=39 |issue=9 |pages=746–56 |date=September 2005 |pmid=16168032 |doi=10.1111/j.1440-1614.2005.01678.x}}</ref>
Poorer general health has been found among individuals with severe mental illnesses, thought to be due to direct and indirect factors including diet, bacterial infections, substance use, exercise levels, effects of medications, socioeconomic disadvantages, lowered help-seeking or treatment adherence, or poorer healthcare provision.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Phelan |first1= M |last2= Stradins |first2= L |last3= Morrison |first3= S |title=Physical health of people with severe mental illness: Can be improved if primary care and mental health professionals pay attention to it |journal=BMJ |volume=322 |issue=7284 |pages=443–4 |date=February 2001 |pmid= 11222406 |pmc=1119672 |url=http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/322/7284/443#B8 |doi=10.1136/bmj.322.7284.443}}</ref> Some chronic general medical conditions have been linked to some aspects of mental disorder, such as [[AIDS]]-related psychosis.
The current research on Lyme's disease caused by a deer tick, and related toxins, is expanding the link between bacterial infections and mental illness.<ref>[https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/mentaldisorders.html Mental Disorders: MedlinePlus<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Research shows that infections and exposure to toxins such as [[HIV]] and [[streptococcus]] cause dementia and OCD respectively.<ref name="webmd.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}}<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Perry |first1=SW |title=Organic mental disorders caused by HIV: Update on early diagnosis and treatment |journal=The American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=147 |issue=6 |pages=696–710 |year=1990 |pmid=2188514 |doi=10.1176/ajp.147.6.696 }}</ref> The infections or toxins trigger a change in the brain chemistry, which can develop into a mental disorder.
===Injury and brain defects=== Any damage to the brain can cause a mental disorder. The brain is the control system for the nervous system and the rest of the body. Without it the body cannot function properly.<ref name="netplaces.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}}
Higher rates of mood, psychotic, and substance abuse disorders have been found following [[traumatic brain injury]] (TBI). Findings on the relationship between TBI severity and prevalence of subsequent psychiatric disorders have been inconsistent, and occurrence has been linked to prior mental health problems as well as direct neurophysiological effects, in a complex interaction with personality and attitude and [[social influences]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fann |first1= JR |last2= Burington |first2= B |last3= Leonetti |first3= A |last4= Jaffe |first4= K |last5= Katon |first5= WJ |last6= Thompson |first6= RS |display-authors= 2 |title= Psychiatric illness following traumatic brain injury in an adult health maintenance organization population |journal=Arch Gen Psychiatry |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=53–61 |date=January 2004 |pmid=14706944 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.61.1.53}}</ref>
Head trauma is classified as either open or closed head injury. In [[open head injury]] the skull is penetrated and brain tissue is destroy in a localized area. [[Closed head injury]] is more common, the skull is not penetrated but there is an impact of the brain against the skull which can create permanent structural damage (e.g. [[subdural hematoma]]). With both types, symptoms may disappear or persist over time. It has been found that typically the longer the length of time spent unconscious and the length of [[post-traumatic amnesia]] the worse the prognosis for the individual. The cognitive residual symptoms of head trauma are associated with the type of injury (either open head injury or closed head injury)and the amount of tissue destroyed. Symptoms of closed injury head trauma tend to be the experience of intellectual deficits in [[Abstract reasoning|abstract reasoning ability]], judgement, and memory, and also marked personality changes. Symptoms of open injury head trauma tend to be the experience of classic neuropsychological syndromes like [[aphasia]], visual-spatial disorders, and types of memory or [[Sensory processing disorder|perceptual disorder]]s.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last= Turner |editor1-first= Samuel M. |editor2-last= Hersen |editor2-first= Michel |date= 1984 |series= Wiley Series on Personality Processes |pages= 44–5 |location= Canada |publisher= John Wiley |title= Adult Psychopathology and Diagnosis |edition= 2nd |isbn= 978-0471089698 |ref= harv}}</ref>
Brain tumors are classified as either [[malignant]] and [[benign]], and as [[intrinsic]] (directly infiltrate the [[parenchyma]] of the brain) or [[extrinsic]] (grows on the external surface of the brain and produces symptoms as a result of pressure on the brain tissue). Progressive cognitive changes associated with brain tumors may include confusion, poor comprehension, and even [[dementia]]. Symptoms tend to depend on the location of the tumor on the brain. For example, tumors on the [[frontal lobe]] tend to be associated with the symptoms of impairment of judgment, apathy, and loss of the ability to regulate/modulate behavior.<ref name= TH45-6>{{harvp|Turner|Hersen|1984|pp=45-6}}</ref>
Findings have indicated abnormal functioning of [[brainstem]] structures in individuals with mental disorders such as [[schizophrenia]], and other disorders that have to do with impairments in maintaining sustained attention.<ref name= 2005MirskyDuncan>{{cite journal |last1=Mirsky |first1= AF |last2= Duncan |first2= CC |title=Pathophysiology of mental illness: A view from the fourth ventricle |journal=Int J Psychophysiol. |volume=58 |issue=2–3 |pages=162–78 |year=2005 |pmid=16213042 |doi=10.1016/j.ijpsycho.2005.06.004}}</ref> Some abnormalities in the average size or shape of some regions of the brain have been found in some disorders, reflecting genes and/or experience. Studies of schizophrenia have tended to find enlarged [[ventricular system|ventricles]] and sometimes reduced volume of the [[cerebrum]] and [[hippocampus]], while studies of (psychotic) [[bipolar disorder]] have sometimes found increased [[amygdala]] volume. Findings differ over whether volumetric abnormalities are risk factors or are only found alongside the course of mental health problems, possibly reflecting neurocognitive or emotional stress processes and/or medication use or substance use.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McDonald |first1=C|last2=Marshall |first2=N |last3=Sham |first3=PC |last4=Bullmore |first4=ET |last5=Schulze |first5=K |last6=Chapple |first6=B |last7=Bramon |first7=E |last8=Filbey |first8=F |last9=Quraishi |first9=S |last10=Walshe |first10=M |last11=Murray |first11=RM |display-authors= 2 |title=Regional brain morphometry in patients with schizophrenia or bipolar disorder and their unaffected relatives |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=163 |issue=3 |pages=478–87 |year=2006 |pmid=16513870 |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.163.3.478 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Velakoulis |first1=D |last2=Wood |first2=SJ |last3=Wong |first3=MTH |last4=McGorry |first4=PD |last5=Yung |first5=A |last6=Phillips |first6=L |last7=Smith |first7=D |last8=Brewer |first8=W |last9=Proffitt |first9=T |last10=Desmond |first10=P |last11=Pantelis |first11=C |display-authors= 2 |title=Hippocampal and Amygdala Volumes According to Psychosis Stage and Diagnosis |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=63 |issue=2 |pages=139–49 |year=2006 |pmid=16461856 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.63.2.139 }}</ref> Some studies have also found reduced hippocampal volumes in [[major depression]], possibly worsening with time depressed.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Colla |first1=M |last2=Kronenberg |first2=G |last3=Deuschle |first3=M |last4=Meichel |first4=K |last5=Hagen |first5=T |last6=Bohrer |first6=M |last7=Heuser |first7=I |display-authors= 2 |title=Hippocampal volume reduction and HPA-system activity in major depression |journal=Journal of Psychiatric Research |volume=41 |issue=7 |pages=553–60 |year=2007 |pmid=17023001 |doi=10.1016/j.jpsychires.2006.06.011 }}</ref>
===Neurotransmitter systems=== Abnormal levels of [[dopamine]] activity have been ''correlated'' with a number of disorders (e.g., reduced in [[ADHD]] and [[OCD]], and increased in schizophrenia).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Iversen |first1=SD |last2= Iversen |first2= LL |title=Dopamine: 50 years in perspective |journal=Trends Neurosci. |volume=30 |issue=5 |pages=188–93 |date=May 2007 |pmid=17368565 |doi=10.1016/j.tins.2007.03.002}}</ref> Dysfunction in [[serotonin]] and other [[monoamine]] neurotransmitters (e.g., [[norepinephrine]] and [[dopamine]]), and their associated neural networks, are also moderately correlated with certain mental disorders, including [[major depressive disorder|major depression]], [[obsessive compulsive disorder]], [[phobias]], [[posttraumatic stress disorder]], and [[generalized anxiety disorder]]. Studies of depleted levels of [[monoamine]] neurotransmitters show an association with depression and other psychiatric disorders, but "... it should be questioned whether 5-HT [serotonin] represents just one of the final, and not the main, factors in the neurological chain of events underlying psychopathological symptoms...." <ref>Marazziti, D. (2017). [http://doi.org/10.12688/f1000research.10094.1 Understanding the role of serotonin in psychiatric diseases.] ''F1000Research, 6'', 180. doi:10.12688/f1000research.10094.1 [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5325064/?report=classic PMC5325064].</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ruhé|first1=HG|last2=Mason|first2=NS|last3=Schene|first3=AH|date=April 2007|title=Mood is indirectly related to serotonin, norepinephrine and dopamine levels in humans: A meta-analysis of monoamine depletion studies|journal=Mol Psychiatry|volume=12|issue=4|pages=331–59|doi=10.1038/sj.mp.4001949|pmid=17389902}}</ref>
Simplistic "chemical imbalance" explanations for mental disorders have never received empirical support; and most prominent psychiatrists, neuroscientists, and psychologists have not espoused such ill-defined, facile etiological theories.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/couch-crisis/psychiatrys-new-brain-mind-and-legend-chemical-imbalance|title=Psychiatry’s New Brain-Mind and the Legend of the "Chemical Imbalance" {{!}} Psychiatric Times|website=www.psychiatrictimes.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hindmarch |first1=I |title=Beyond the monoamine hypothesis: Mechanisms, molecules and methods |journal=European Psychiatry |volume=17 Suppl 3 |issue= |pages=294–9 |year=2002 |pmid=15177084 |doi=10.1016/S0924-9338(02)00653-3}}</ref> Instead, neurotransmitter systems have been understood in the context of the [[Diathesis–stress model|diathesis-stress]] or [[biopsychosocial]] models. The following 1967 quote from renowned psychiatric and neuroscience researchers exemplifies this more sophisticated understanding (in contrast to the woolly "chemical imbalance" notion).
<blockquote>Whereas specific genetic factors may be of importance in the etiology of some, and possibly all, depressions, it is equally conceivable that early experiences of the infant or child may cause enduring biochemical changes, and that these may predispose some individuals to depressions in adulthood. It is not likely that changes in the metabolism of the biogenic amines alone will account for the complex phenomena of normal or pathological affect.<ref>Schildkraut, J. J., & Kety, S. S. (1967). Biogenic amines and emotion. ''Science'', 156(3771), 21-30.</ref></blockquote>
===Substance abuse=== Substance abuse, especially long-term abuse, can cause or exacerbate many mental disorders. [[Alcoholism]] is linked to [[depression (mood)|depression]] while abuse of [[amphetamines]] and [[LSD]] can leave a person feeling [[paranoid]] and [[anxious]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.med.unc.edu/alcohol/prevention/health.html |title= Effects of Alcohol and Drug Abuse; ...On your Health |accessdate= 8 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522233612/http://www.med.unc.edu/alcohol/prevention/health.html |archivedate=22 May 2013 |publisher= Bowles Center for Alcohol Studies: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill }}</ref>
Correlations of mental disorders with drug use include [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]],<ref name="rcpsych.ac.uk"/> alcohol and [[caffeine]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Winston |first1=AP |title=Neuropsychiatric effects of caffeine |journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment |volume=11 |issue=6 |year=2005 |pages=432–9 |doi=10.1192/apt.11.6.432 }}</ref> [[Caffeine]] use is correlated with [[anxiety]]<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vilarim |first1=MM |last2=Rocha Araujo |first2=DM |last3=Nardi |first3=AE |title=Caffeine challenge test and panic disorder: a systematic literature review |journal=Expert Review of Neurotherapeutics |volume=11 |issue=8 |pages=1185–95 |year=2011 |pmid=21797659 |doi=10.1586/ern.11.83 }}</ref> and suicide. Illicit drugs have the ability to stimulate particular parts of the brain which can affect development in adolescence. Cannabis has been found to worsen depression and lessen an individual's [[motivation]].<ref name="rcpsych.ac.uk"/> Alcohol has the potential to damage "[[white matter]]" in the brain which affects [[thinking]] and [[memory]]. Alcohol has been found to be a serious problem in many countries due to many people participating in excessive drinking or [[binge drinking]].
==Life experience and environmental factors==
The term "environment" is very loosely defined when it comes to mental illness. Unlike biological and psychological causes, environmental causes are stressors that individuals deal with in everyday life. These stressors range from financial issues to having low self-esteem. Environmental causes are more psychologically based thus making them more closely related.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mentalhealth-jami.org.uk/causes-of-mental-illness |title= Causes of Mental Illness |website= www.mentalhealth.jami.org.uk |date= |accessdate= |publisher= }}</ref>{{Unreliable medical source|date=November 2017}} Events that evoke feelings of loss or damage are most likely to cause a mental disorder to develop in an individual.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Schmidt |first1=CW |title=Environmental connections: A deeper look into mental illness |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=115 |issue=8 |pages=A404, A406–10 |year=2007 |pmid=17687431 |pmc=1940091 |doi=10.1289/ehp.115-a404}}</ref> Environmental factors include but are not limited a dysfunctional home life, poor relationships with others, substance abuse, not meeting social expectations, low self-esteem and poverty.<ref name="webmd.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}}
[[Mind (charity)|Mind]] mentions childhood abuse, trauma, violence or neglect, social isolation, loneliness or discrimination, the death of someone close, stress, homelessness or poor housing, social disadvantage, poverty or debt, unemployment, caring for a family member or friend, significant trauma as an adult, such as military combat, and being involved in a serious accident or being the victim of a violent crime as possibly triggering an episode of mental illness.<ref name="mind.org.uk"/>
Repeating generational patterns have been found to be a risk factor for mental illness.<ref name=pmid24206921/><ref name="academia.edu"/>
===Life events and emotional stress=== It is reported that treatment in childhood and in adulthood, including [[sexual abuse]], [[physical abuse]], [[emotional abuse]], [[domestic violence]] and [[bullying]], has been linked to the development of mental disorders, through a complex interaction of societal, family, psychological and biological factors.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Spataro |first1=J |last2=Mullen |first2=PE |last3=Burgess |first3=PM |last4=Wells |first4=DL |last5=Moss |first5=SA |display-authors= 2 |title=Impact of child sexual abuse on mental health: Prospective study in males and females |journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=184 |issue= 5|pages=416–21 |year=2004 |pmid=15123505 |doi=10.1192/bjp.184.5.416 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Maughan |first1=B |last2=McCarthy |first2=G |title=Childhood adversities and psychosocial disorders |journal=British Medical Bulletin |volume=53 |issue=1 |pages=156–69 |year=1997 |pmid=9158291 |doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.bmb.a011597 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Teicher |first1= MH |last2= Samson |first2= JA |last3= Polcari |first3= A |last4= McGreenery |first4= CE |display-authors= 2 |title=Sticks, stones, and hurtful words: Relative effects of various forms of childhood maltreatment |journal=Am J Psychiatry |volume=163 |issue=6 |pages= 993–1000 |date=June 2006 |pmid=16741199 |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.163.6.993}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kessler |first1= RC |last2= Davis |first2= CG |last3= Kendler |first3= KS |title=Childhood adversity and adult psychiatric disorder in the US National Comorbidity Survey |journal=Psychol. Med. |volume=27 |issue=5 |pages=1101–19 |date=September 1997 |pmid=9300515 |doi= 10.1017/S0033291797005588}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pirkola |first1=S |last2=Isometsä |first2=E |last3=Aro |first3=H |last4=Kestilä |first4=L |last5=Hämäläinen |first5=J |last6=Veijola |first6=J |last7=Kiviruusu |first7=O |last8=Lönnqvist |first8=J |display-authors= 2 |title=Childhood adversities as risk factors for adult mental disorders |journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology |volume=40 |issue=10 |pages=769–77 |year=2005 |pmid=16205853 |doi=10.1007/s00127-005-0950-x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=MacMillan |first1=HL |last2=Fleming |first2=JE |last3=Streiner |first3=DL |last4=Lin |first4=E |last5=Boyle |first5=MH |last6=Jamieson |first6=E |last7=Duku |first7=EK |last8=Walsh |first8=CA |last9=Wong |first9=MY-Y |last10=Beardslee |first10=WR |display-authors= 2 |title=Childhood abuse and lifetime psychopathology in a community sample |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=158 |issue=11 |pages=1878–83 |year=2001 |pmid=11691695 |doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.158.11.1878 }}</ref> Negative or stressful life events more generally have been implicated in the development of a range of disorders, including mood and anxiety disorders.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jeronimus |first1=BF |last2=Ormel |first2=J |last3=Aleman |first3=A |last4=Penninx |first4=BWJH |last5=Riese |first5=H |display-authors= 2 |title=Negative and positive life events are associated with small but lasting change in neuroticism |journal=Psychological Medicine |volume=43 |issue=11 |year=2013 |pages=2403–15 |doi=10.1017/S0033291713000159 |pmid=23410535}}</ref> The main risks appear to be from a cumulative combination of such experiences over time, although exposure to a single major trauma can sometimes lead to psychopathology, including [[PTSD]]. [[Psychological resilience|Resilience]] to such experiences varies, and a person may be resistant to some forms of experience but susceptible to others. Features associated with variations in resilience include genetic vulnerability, temperamental characteristics, cognitive set, coping patterns, and other experiences.<ref name=Rutter2000>{{cite journal |last=Rutter |first= M |title=Psychosocial influences: Critiques, findings, and research needs |journal=Dev Psychopathol. |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=375–405 |year=2000 |pmid=11014744 |doi=10.1017/S0954579400003072}}</ref>
For [[bipolar disorder]], stress (such as childhood adversity) is not a specific cause, but does place genetically and biologically vulnerable individuals at risk for a more severe course of illness.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1017/S0954579408000424 |title=Prevention of bipolar disorder in at-risk children: Theoretical assumptions and empirical foundations |year=2008 |last1=Miklowitz |first1=DJ |last2=Chang |first2=KD |journal=Development and Psychopathology |volume=20 |issue=3 |pmid=18606036 |pages=881–97 |pmc=2504732}}</ref>
===Poor parenting, abuse and neglect===
Poor parenting has been found to be a risk factor for depression<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and anxiety.<ref name="National Academies Press"/><ref name="Bienvenu Ginsburg 2007"/> Separation or bereavement in families, and childhood trauma, have been found to be risk factors for psychosis and schizophrenia.<ref name="schizophreniacommission.org.uk"/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Varese |first1=F |last2=Smeets |first2=F |last3=Drukker |first3=M |last4=Lieverse |first4=R |last5=Lataster |first5=T |last6=Viechtbauer |first6=W |last7=Read |first7=J |last8=van Os |first8=J |last9=Bentall |first9=RP |display-authors= 2 |title=Childhood adversities increase the risk of psychosis: A meta-analysis of patient-control, prospective- and cross-sectional cohort Studies |journal=Schizophrenia Bulletin |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=661–71 |year=2012 |pmid=22461484 |pmc=3406538 |doi=10.1093/schbul/sbs050 }}</ref>
Severe psychological trauma such as abuse can wreak havoc on a person's life. Children are much more susceptible to psychological harm from traumatic events than adults. Once again, the reaction to the trauma will vary based on the person as well as the individual's age. The impact of these events is influenced by several factors: the type of event, the length of exposure the individual had to the event, and the extent to which the individual and their family/friends were personally affected by the event. Human-caused disasters, such as a tumultuous childhood affect children more than natural disasters<ref name="Feldman, P. 2012 p. 347">{{harvp|Feldman|Papalia|2012|p=347}}</ref>
[[Neglect]] is a type of maltreatment related to the failure to provide needed, age-appropriate care, supervision and protection. It is not to be confused with [[abuse]], which, in this context, is defined as any action that intentionally harms or injures another person.<ref>medical-dictionary.com</ref>{{Full citation needed|date=November 2017}} Neglect most often happens during childhood by the parents or caretakers. Oftentimes, parents who are guilty of neglect were also neglected as children. The long-term effects of neglect are reduced physical, emotional, and mental health in a child and throughout adulthood.<ref name="Feldman, P. 2012 p. 347"/>
===The Adverse Childhood Experiences Study===
Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are various forms of [[child maltreatment|maltreatment]] and household dysfunction experienced in childhood. The [[Adverse Childhood Experiences Study]] has shown a strong [[dose–response relationship]] between ACEs and numerous health, social, and behavioral problems throughout a person's lifespan, including suicide attempts and frequency of depressive episodes.<ref name=SAMHSA_ACE/> Children's neurological development can be disrupted when they are chronically exposed to stressful events such as physical, emotional, or sexual abuse, physical or emotional neglect, witnessing violence in the household, or a parent being incarcerated or suffering from a mental illness. As a result, the child's cognitive functioning or ability to cope with negative or disruptive emotions may be impaired. Over time, the child may adopt various harmful coping strategies that can contribute to later disease and disability.<ref name=SAMHSA_ACE>{{cite web |title=Adverse Childhood Experiences |publisher=Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration |location=Rockville, Maryland, United States |website=samhsa.gov |url=http://www.samhsa.gov/capt/practicing-effective-prevention/prevention-behavioral-health/adverse-childhood-experiences |access-date=February 2016}}</ref>
===Relationships=== Relationship issues have been consistently linked to the development of mental disorders, with continuing debate on the relative impact of the home environment or work/school and peer groups. Issues with parenting skills or parental depression or other problems may be a risk factor. Parental divorce appears to increase risk, perhaps only if there is family discord or disorganization, although a warm supportive relationship with one parent may compensate. Details of infant feeding, weaning, toilet training etc. do not appear to be importantly linked to psychopathology. Early social privation, or lack of ongoing, harmonious, secure, committed relationships, have been implicated in the development of mental disorders.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heinrich |first1= LM |last2= Gullone |first2= E |title=The clinical significance of loneliness: A literature review |journal=Clin Psychol Rev |volume=26 |issue=6 |pages=695–718 |date=October 2006 |pmid=16952717 |doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2006.04.002}}</ref>
Some approaches, such as certain theories of [[co-counseling]], may see all non-neurological mental disorders as the result of the self-regulating mechanisms of the mind (which accompany the physical expression of emotions) not being allowed to operate.
How an individual interacts with others as well as the quality of relationships can greatly increase or decrease a person's quality of living. Continuous fighting with friends and family can all lead to an increased risk of developing a mental illness. A [[dysfunctional family]] may include disobedience, child neglect and/or abuse which occurs regularly. These types of families are often a product of an unhealthy co-dependent relationship on the part of the head of the household (usually to drugs).
Losing a loved one, especially at an early age can have lasting effects on an individual. The individual may feel fear, guilt, anger or loneliness. This can drive a person into solitude and depression. They may turn to alcohol and drugs to cope with their feelings.
[[Divorce]] is also another factor that can take a toll on both children and adults alike. Divorcees may suffer from emotional adjustment problems due to a loss of intimacy and social connections. Newer statistics show that the negative effects of divorce have been greatly exaggerated.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mediate.com/articles/psych.cfm |title= Psychological and Emotional Aspects of Divorce<!-- Bot generated title --> |website= www.meditate.com}}</ref>{{Unreliable medical source|date=November 2017}} The effects of divorce in children are based on three main factors: the quality of their relationship with each of their parents before the separation, the intensity and duration of the parental conflict, and the parents' ability to focus on the needs of children in their divorce.
===Social expectations and esteem=== How individuals view themselves ultimately determines who they are, their abilities and what they can be. Having both too low of [[self-esteem]] as well as too high of one can be detrimental to an individual's mental health.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mann |first1=M |last2=Hosman |first2=CM |last3=Schaalma |first3=HP |last4=de Vries |first4=NK |display-authors= 2 |title=Self-esteem in a broad-spectrum approach for mental health promotion |journal=Health Education Research |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=357–72 |year=2004 |pmid=15199011 |doi=10.1093/her/cyg041 }}</ref> A person's self-esteem plays a much larger role in their overall happiness and quality of life. Poor self-esteem whether it be too high or too low can result in aggression, violence, self-deprecating behavior, anxiety, and other mental disorders.
Not fitting in with the masses can result in bullying and other types of emotional abuse. Bullying can result in depression, feelings of anger, loneliness.
===Poverty=== {{See|Socioeconomic status and mental health}}
Studies show that there is a direct correlation between [[poverty]] and mental illness. The lower the socioeconomic status of an individual the higher the risk of mental illness. Impoverished people are actually two to three times more likely to develop mental illness than those of a higher economic class.
Low levels of self-efficiency and self-worth are commonly experienced by children of disadvantaged families or those from the economic underclass. Theorists of child development have argued that persistent poverty leads to high levels of psychopathology and poor self-concepts.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/2095905 |jstor=2095905 |title=Poverty, Parenting, and Children's Mental Health |journal=American Sociological Review |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=351–66 |year=1993 |last1=McLeod |first1=Jane D |last2=Shanahan |first2=Michael J }}</ref>
This increased risk for psychiatric complications remains consistent for all individuals among the impoverished population, regardless of any in-group demographic differences that they may possess.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Poverty and psychiatric status: Longitudinal evidence from the New Haven Epidemiologic Catchment Area Study|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=48|issue=5|pages=470–474|doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1991.01810290082015|year=1991|author=Livingston Bruce Martha}}</ref> These families must deal with economic stressors like unemployment and lack of affordable housing, which can lead to mental health disorders. A person's socioeconomic class outlines the [[psychosocial]], environmental, behavioral, and [[biomedical]] risk factors that are associated with mental health.<ref>{{cite web |title= Mental Illness and Poverty: A Fact Sheet |url= http://www.fccmh.org/resources/docs/MentalIllnessandPovery.pdf |date= January 2007 |accessdate= |publisher= Florida Council for Community Mental Health |website= www.fccmh.org}}</ref>
According to findings there is a strong association between poverty and [[substance abuse]]. Substance abuse only perpetuates a continuous cycle. It can make it extremely difficult for individuals to find and keep jobs. As stated earlier, both financial problems and substance abuse can cause mental illnesses to develop.<ref>[http://www.everythingaddiction.com/addiction-society/substance-abuse-and-poverty Substance Abuse and Poverty | Addiction<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Communities and cultures=== Mental disorders have been linked to the overarching social, economic and cultural system.<ref name=Fee>{{cite book |last= Fee |first= D |date= 2000 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YYyfbJKnbOEC&pg |title= Pathology and the Postmodern: Mental Illness as Discourse and Experience |location= London |publisher= Sage |page= |isbn= 9780761952534}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=November 2017}}<ref name=AlIssa>{{cite book |last=Al-Issa |first= Ihsan |title=Handbook of Culture and Mental Illness: An International Perspective |publisher=International Universities Press |location=New York |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-8236-2288-7}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=November 2017}}<ref name= Krause>{{cite journal |last = Krause |first= I | year = 2006 | title = Hidden points of view in cross-cultural psychotherapy and ethnography | url = | journal = Transcultural Psychiatry | volume = 43 | issue = 2| pages = 181–203 | doi=10.1177/1363461506064848|pmid= 16893871 }}</ref><ref name=RichardsBergin>{{cite book |last1=Bergin |first1= Allen E. |last2=Richards |first2= P.J. |title=Handbook of Psychotherapy and Religious Diversity |publisher=American Psychological Association (APA) |year=2000 |isbn=978-1-55798-624-5}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=November 2017}}<ref name=Littlewood>{{cite book |last1=Lipsedge |first1= Maurice |last2=Littlewood |first2= Roland |title=Aliens and Alienists: Ethnic Minorities and Psychiatry |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-415-15725-4 |edition=3rd}}</ref> Some non-Western views take this community approach.<ref name="mentalhealth.freeuk.com"/>
Problems in communities or cultures, including poverty, unemployment or [[underemployment]], lack of social cohesion, and migration, have been <span style="color:crimson;">associated with</span> the development of mental disorders.<ref name="Rogers&Pilgram05"/><ref name="Rutter2000"/> Stresses and strains related to socioeconomic position ([[socioeconomics|socioeconomic status]] (SES) or [[social class]]) have been linked to the occurrence of major mental disorders, with a lower or more insecure educational, occupational, economic or social position generally linked to more mental disorders.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Muntaner |first1=C |last2=Eaton |first2=WW |last3=Miech |first3=R |last4=O'Campo |first4=P |display-authors= 2 |title=Socioeconomic position and major mental disorders |journal=Epidemiologic Reviews |volume=26 |issue= |pages=53–62 |year=2004 |pmid=15234947 |doi=10.1093/epirev/mxh001 }}</ref> There have been mixed findings on the nature of the links and on the extent to which pre-existing personal characteristics influence the links. Both personal resources and community factors have been implicated, as well as interactions between individual-level and regional-level income levels.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lorant |first1=V |last2=Deliège |first2=D |last3=Eaton |first3=W |last4=Robert |first4=A |last5=Philippot |first5=P |last6=Ansseau |first6=M |display-authors= 2 |title=Socioeconomic inequalities in depression: a meta-analysis |journal=American Journal of Epidemiology |volume=157 |issue=2 |pages=98–112 |year=2003 |pmid=12522017 |doi=10.1093/aje/kwf182 }}</ref> The causal role of different socioeconomic factors may vary by country.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Araya |first1=R |last2=Lewis |first2=G |last3=Rojas |first3=G |last4=Fritsch |first4=R |display-authors= 2 |title=Education and income: Which is more important for mental health? |journal=Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health |volume=57 |issue=7 |pages=501–5 |year=2003 |pmid=12821693 |pmc=1732519 |doi=10.1136/jech.57.7.501 }}</ref> Socioeconomic deprivation in neighborhoods can cause worse mental health, even after accounting for genetic factors.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Caspi |first1=A |last2=Taylor |first2=A |last3=Moffitt |first3=TE |last4=Plomin |first4=R |display-authors= 2 |title=Neighborhood deprivation affects children's mental health: Environmental risks identified in a genetic design |journal=Psychological Science |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=338–42 |year=2000 |pmid=11273396 |doi=10.1111/1467-9280.00267 }}</ref> In addition, minority [[ethnic]] groups, including first or second-generation [[immigrants]], have been found to be at greater risk for developing mental disorders, which has been attributed to various kinds of life insecurities and disadvantages, including [[racism]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chakraborty |first1=A |last2=McKenzie |first2=K |title=Does racial discrimination cause mental illness? |journal=The British Journal of Psychiatry |volume=180 |issue= 6|pages=475–7 |year=2002 |pmid=12042221 |doi=10.1192/bjp.180.6.475 }}</ref> The direction of causality is sometimes unclear, and alternative hypotheses such as the [[Drift Hypothesis]] sometimes need to be discounted.
==Psychological and individual factors, including resilience== Some clinicians believe that psychological characteristics alone determine mental disorders. Others speculate that abnormal behavior can be explained by a mix of social and psychological factors. In many examples, environmental and psychological triggers complement one another resulting in emotional stress, which in turn activates a mental illness<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ahn |first1=W-k |last2=Proctor |first2=CC |last3=Flanagan |first3=EH |title=Mental health clinicians’ beliefs about the biological, psychological, and environmental bases of mental disorders |journal=Cognitive Science |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=147–182 |year=2009 |pmid=20411158 |pmc=2857376 |doi=10.1111/j.1551-6709.2009.01008.x }}</ref> Each person is unique in how they will react to psychological stressors. What may break one person may have little to no effect on another. Psychological stressors, which can trigger mental illness, are as follows: emotional, physical or sexual abuse, loss of a significant loved one, neglect and being unable to relate to others.<ref name="webmd.com"/>{{Better source|date=November 2017}}
The inability to relate to others is also known as [[emotional detachment]]. Emotional detachment makes it difficult for an individual to empathize with others or to share their own feelings. An emotionally detached person may try to rationalize or apply logic to a situation to which there is no logical explanation. These individuals tend to stress the importance of their independence and may be a bit [[neuroticism|neurotic]].<ref>{{cite web |last= Schreiner |first= Michael |url= http://www.evolutioncounseling.com/detached-personality.html |title= Detached Personality |work= Evolution Counseling |publisher= Michael Schreiner |date= 8 December 2011}}</ref>{{Better source|date=November 2017}} Oftentimes, the inability to relate to others stems from a traumatic event.
Mental characteristics of individuals, as assessed by both neurological and psychological studies, have been linked to the development and maintenance of mental disorders. This includes cognitive or [[neurocognitive]] factors, such as the way a person perceives, thinks or feels about certain things;<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Iacoviello |first1= BM |last2=Alloy |first2=LB |last3=Abramson |first3=LY |last4=Whitehouse |first4=WG |last5=Hogan |first5= ME |display-authors= 2 |title=The course of depression in individuals at high and low cognitive risk for depression: A prospective study |journal=J. Affect. Disord. |volume=93 |issue=1–3 |pages=61–9 |date=July 2006 |pmid=16545464 |doi=10.1016/j.jad.2006.02.012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Peer |first1=JE |last2=Rothmann |first2=TL |last3=Penrod |first3=RD |last4=Penn |first4=DL |last5=Spaulding |first5= WD |display-authors= 2 |title=Social cognitive bias and neurocognitive deficit in paranoid symptoms: evidence for an interaction effect and changes during treatment |journal=[[Schizophrenia Research]] |volume=71 |issue=2–3 |pages=463–71 |date=December 2004 |pmid=15474917 |doi=10.1016/j.schres.2004.03.016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bell |first1= V |last2= Halligan |first2= PW |last3= Ellis |first3= HD |title=Explaining delusions: A cognitive perspective |journal=Trends Cogn Sci |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=219–26 |date=May 2006 |pmid=16600666 |doi= 10.1016/j.tics.2006.03.004}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Weems |first1= CF |last2= Costa |first2= NM |last3= Watts |first3= SE |last4= Taylor |first4= LK |last5= Cannon |first5= MF |display-authors= 2 |title=Cognitive errors, anxiety sensitivity, and anxiety control beliefs: Their unique and specific associations with childhood anxiety symptoms |journal=Behav Modif. |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=174–201 |date=March 2007 |pmid=17307934 |doi= 10.1177/0145445506297016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brunelin |first1=J |last2=d'Amato |first2=T |last3=Brun |first3=P |last4=Bediou |first4=B |last5=Kallel |first5=L |last6=Senn |first6=M |last7=Poulet |first7=E |last8=Saoud |first8=M |display-authors= 2 |title=Impaired verbal source monitoring in schizophrenia: An intermediate trait vulnerability marker? |journal=Schizophrenia Research |volume=89 |issue=1–3 |pages=287–92 |year=2007 |pmid=17029909 |doi=10.1016/j.schres.2006.08.028 }}</ref> or an individual's overall personality,<ref name="NeuroticismMA"/> [[temperament]] or [[Coping Mechanisms|coping style]]<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gil |first1=S |last2= Caspi |first2= Y |title=Personality traits, coping style, and perceived threat as predictors of posttraumatic stress disorder after exposure to a terrorist attack: A prospective study |journal=Psychosom. Med. |volume=68 |issue=6 |pages=904–9 |year=2006 |pmid=17079704 |doi= 10.1097/01.psy.0000242124.21796.f8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Brandes |first1= M |last2= Bienvenu |first2= OJ |title=Personality and anxiety disorders |journal=Curr Psychiatry Rep |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=263–9 |date=August 2006 |pmid=16879789 |doi=10.1007/s11920-006-0061-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Christensen |first1=MV |last2= Kessing |first2= LV |title=Do personality traits predict first onset in depressive and bipolar disorder? |journal=Nord J Psychiatry |volume=60 |issue=2 |pages=79–88 |year=2006 |pmid=16635925 |doi=10.1080/08039480600600300 }}</ref> or the extent of protective factors or "positive illusions" such as optimism, personal control and a sense of meaning.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Taylor |first1= SE |last2=Stanton |first2= AL | year = 2007 | title = Coping resources, coping processes, and mental health | journal = Annual Review of Clinical Psychology | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 377–401 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.clinpsy.3.022806.091520 | pmid = 17716061 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mathews |first1=A |last2=MacLeod |first2=C |title=Cognitive vulnerability to emotional disorders |journal=Annual Review of Clinical Psychology |volume=1 |issue=1 |year=2005 |pages=167–95 |doi=10.1146/annurev.clinpsy.1.102803.143916 |pmid=17716086 }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''Charles Handfield Jones''' (1819–1890) was an English physician. [[File:Charles Handfield Jones.jpg|thumb|Charles Handfield Jones]]
==Life== The son of Captain Jones, R.N., he was born in [[Liverpool]], 1 October 1819. He was one of [[Thomas Arnold]]'s pupils at [[Rugby School]], went on to [[Catharine Hall, Cambridge]] in 1837, and graduated B.A. in 1840. After study at [[St. George's Hospital]], London, he took the degree of M.B. at Cambridge in 1843, but never proceeded to that of M.D.<ref name="DNB">{{cite DNB|wstitle=Jones, Charles Handfield|volume=30}}</ref><ref>{{acad|id=JNS836CH|name=Jones, Charles Handfield}}</ref>
Jones became a member of the [[College of Physicians of London]] in 1845, and was elected a fellow in 1849. He published a paper of observations on the minute structure of the [[liver]], which led to his election as fellow of the [[Royal Society]] in 1850. In 1851 he was elected physician to [[St. Mary's Hospital, Paddington]], and continued on the staff of there till his death.<ref name="DNB"/>
Jones attained a reputation as a [[histologist]] and as a clinical observer. In the College of Physicians he was junior censor in 1863–4 and senior censor in 1886, and in 1888 a vice-president. In 1865 he delivered the [[Lumleian lectures]] on the pathology of the nervous system.<ref name="DNB"/>
Resident in Green Street, [[Park Lane, London|Park Lane]], Jones in later years, moved to [[Montagu Square]], London. He died there of cancer of the stomach, 30 September 1890.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Works== Jones published with [[Edward Henry Sieveking]], in 1854, a ''Manual of Pathological Anatomy'', and in 1864 ''Clinical Observations on Functional Nervous Disorders''. He wrote also papers in medical journals, the ''Transactions of the Medico-Chirurgical Society of London'', and the ''Transactions of the Pathological Society''.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Family== Jones married in 1851 Louisa Holt, and had two sons, who both went into the medical profession.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
;Attribution {{DNB|wstitle=Jones, Charles Handfield|volume=30}}
