revision.comment: /* STPs and the use of technology */
revision.text:
The '''Medical Technology Group''' ('''MTG''') is a not for profit organisation in the [[United Kingdom]] comprising patient groups, research [[charities]] and [[medical device]] manufacturers. Its stated aim is to "work together to improve patient access to effective [[Health technology|medical technologies]]". The Group launched in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Early Day Motion 216, 2000-01|url=http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2000-01/216|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>
== Membership ==
Current members of the MTG are: * [http://www.abbott.co.uk/ Abbott] * ABHI * [http://www.actionduchenne.org/ Action Duchenne] * [[AdvaMed]] * AntiCoagulation Europe * ARMA * Arrhythmia Alliance * [[Arthritis Care]] * [[Atrial Fibrillation Association]] * [[Becton Dickinson|BD (Becton Dickinson)]] * [[Boston Scientific]] * [http://www.bcpa.eu/default.htm British Cardiac Patients Association] * [http://www.Bard.co.uk C R Bard] * Cardiomyopathy Association * [[Diabetes UK]] * [[Edwards Lifesciences]] * [[Eucomed]] * FABLE * FEmISA * [[Fight_for_Sight_(UK)|Fight for Sight]] * [http://heartresearch.org.uk Heart Research UK] * [http://www.heartvalvevoice.com Heart Valve Voice] * ICD Group * INPUT Patient Advocacy * [http://www.insightec.com/ InSightec] * International Alliance of Patients' Organisations * [[JDRF]] * [[Johnson & Johnson]] * Lindsay Leg Club * [https://www.macmillan.org.uk MacMillan Cancer Support] * [[Medtronic]] * National Rheumatoid Arthritis Society * [http://www.pancreaticcancer.org.uk/ Pancreatic Cancer UK] * Pelvic Pain Support Network * [http://pumpingmarvellous.org/ Pumping Marvellous Foundation] * [[Roche Diagnostics]] * SADS UK * [http://www.smiths-medical.com Smiths Medical] * [[Smith & Nephew]] * STARS * [[Stryker Corporation|Stryker]] * The Circulation Foundation * [[Patients Association|The Patients Association]] * Transplant Support Network
== Research ==
=== <small>STPs and the use of technology</small> ===
Nine out of ten regional NHS plans are failing to pay enough attention to the role of medical technology, a report by the Medical Technology Group report found in November 2018. All 44 regional STP plans were analysed in the report ‘[https://mtg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/STPs-and-the-use-of-technology-low-res.pdf STPs and the use of technology]’, which concluded that the NHS is risking missing out on the opportunity to benefit from the use of innovative medical technology. Seven recommendations for ensuring healthcare systems assess, procure, commission and deliver technology-based treatments effectively are set out in the report.<ref>{{cite news |title=NHS regional plans not valuing medical tech |url=http://www.healthbusinessuk.net/news/14112018/nhs-regional-plans-not-valuing-medical-tech |accessdate=15 November 2018 |publisher=Health Business |date=15 November 2018}}</ref>
=== <small>Keeping Britain Working: How medical technology can help reduce the cost of ill health to the UK economy</small> ===
In November 2017, The Medical Technology Group launched its second major study, ‘[http://www.mtg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/Keeping-Britain-Working-Report-web.pdf Keeping Britain Working – How medical technology can help reduce the cost of ill health to the UK economy]’. Building on the [http://www.mtg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Adding-Value-The-Economic-and-Societal-Benefits-of-Medical-Technology.pdf Work Foundation’s 2011 study], the report explores the societal and economic impact of eight technologies: hip replacements; implantable cardiac defibrillators (ICDs); insulin pumps; diagnostics, including sepsis; fibroid embolisation; pain management; wound care; and coronary angioplasty. The report concluded that £476 million in savings per year could be generated from the use of eight technologies in reduced long-term health costs and benefit payments.<ref>{{cite web|title=NHS is 'missing a trick' by opting for cheaper treatment options, report warns|url=https://www.buildingbetterhealthcare.co.uk/news/article_page/NHS_is_missing_a_trick_by_opting_for_cheaper_treatment_options_report_warns/136961|website=Building Better Healthcare|publisher=HPCi Media Limited|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>
=== <small>The North-South NHS divide: how where you are - not what you need - dictates your care</small> === A review of all 209 Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) in England - published in August 2017 - revealed wide variation in waiting times and access to medical technology for patients. The study [http://www.mtg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/The-North-South-NHS-divide-how-where-you-are-not-what-you-need-dictates-your-care-FINAL-low-res.pdf The North-South NHS divide: how where you are - not what you need - dictates your care] examined five clinical areas in NHS 18 Week Referral to Treatment and NHS Atlas of Variation data. It found that nine out of ten of the poorest performing CCGs were based in the south of England and that almost three times more patients were waiting longer than 18 weeks for treatment compared with November 2012. The report made seven recommendations for improvement including greater transparency so that patients can compare the performance of their local health service and inspections of the poorest performing CCGs by [[NHS England]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Nicola|title=NHS waiting times and treatment access are a postcode lottery, report warns|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/aug/15/nhs-waiting-times-and-treatment-access-are-a-postcode-lottery-report-warns|accessdate=15 August 2017|publisher=Guardian News & Media|date=15 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Pym|first1=Hugh|title=How bad is the NHS postcode lottery?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-40927705|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=15 August 2017}}</ref>
=== <small>Déjà Review – what lessons can be learned from the past?</small> === In June 2016, the Medical Technology Group published its report '[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B60cHNIWGkbiT0dTelYtQUd1c0k/view Déjà Review – what lessons can be learned from the past?]'. The report identified 17 different organisations or initiatives that have been launched with the aim of promoting innovation in the NHS over the previous ten years. In Déjà Review, the MTG noted that the NHS has historically and consistently failed to apply any learnings from the previous reviews, including 2011’s much-quoted Innovation, Health and Wealth (IHW).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/wellbeing/health-advice/wasteful-nhs-reports-could-pay-for-drugs/|title=Wasteful NHS reports could pay for drugs|website=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref>
=== <small>Unplanned admissions</small> ===
In 2015 the Medical Technology Group contacted every acute Trust and Clinical Commissioning Group in England to identify the level of unplanned or emergency hospital admissions for urology, diabetes and heart failure. The research found that unplanned and emergency hospital admissions account for more than a third of all hospital admissions – 5.4 million in total – and two thirds of all hospital bed days. It also found that the NHS spent £434 million in 2013/14 treating over 180,000 hospital patients with an unplanned admission for a urinary tract infection; unplanned admissions owing to diabetic complications cost over £200 million each year. Additional findings were that each NHS Trust handles on average over 100 deaths each year from congestive heart failure, but with regional differences in approach and success rates: for example 66% of presenting heart patients in the Southwest were treated in hospital compared to just 16% in the West Midlands.<ref name=Arwatch>{{cite web|title=Better use of technology could slash A&E costs|url=http://arwatch.co.uk/2015/11/better-use-of-technology-could-slash-ae-costs/|website=Arryhthmia Watch|publisher=British Journal of Cardiology|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Health Business|title=Accessing all areas of medical technology|url=https://issuu.com/psi-media/docs/hb16.2|accessdate=29 April 2016|issue=Volume 6.2|publisher=Public Sector Information Ltd|date=April 2016}}</ref>
=== <small>Innovation, Health & Wealth Scorecard</small> ===
In June 2015 the MTG published its review of the 2011 Innovation, Health & Wealth report by NHS Improvement & Efficiency, Innovation and Service Improvement. The [http://www.mtg.org.uk/press-releases/innovation-health-and-wealth-scorecard Scorecard] reviewed progress against the six areas identified by the NHS as those where Clinical Commissioning Groups and acute Trusts could improve patient care through high impact innovations. The report revealed a very mixed picture, with both CCGs and Trusts in some areas performing much worse than others, and some regions of the country drastically underperforming.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harpham|first1=Barbara|title=Innovation adoption: stuck in the slow lane?|journal=Clinical Services Journal|date=August 2015|url=http://www.clinicalservicesjournal.com/story/14626/innovation-adoption-stuck-in-the-slow-lane|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
=== <small>Infection control</small> ===
Following a [[Freedom of Information]] request to all NHS Acute Trusts in England, in September 2014 the MTG published a report: [http://www.mtg.org.uk/bulletins/infection-prevention-and-control-combating-problem-has-not-gone-away Infection Prevention and Control – Combatting a problem that has not gone away] that revealed that the majority of Trusts were unaware of the full scale or the operational and financial impact of five common infections: [[sepsis]]; catheter-associated [[urinary tract infections]]; catheter-related blood infections; [[ventilator]]-associated [[pneumonia]]; and [[norovirus]]. The MTG called on the Government to develop a strategy for using technology for infection prevention and control.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Adrian|first1=O’Dowd|title=British Medical Journal|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/349/bmj.g5656|accessdate=19 September 2014|publisher=BMJ|date=15 September 2014|ref=BMJ 2014;349:g5656}}</ref>
=== <small>Hip and knee surgery</small> ===
In November 2013, the MTG published a report into waiting times for knee and hip replacements on the [[National Health Service (England)|National Health Service]]. The report, ''Hip and Knee Surgery: Combating Patient Lotteries'', reviewed ten years of government data on knee and hip replacement, and data from [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information]] requests to [[NHS Trust|acute NHS hospital trusts]] in England.<ref>http://www.mtg.org.uk/images/Spotlight/Hip_and_Knee_Replacements_-_Combating_Patient_Lotteries.pdf</ref> The report suggested that patient experiences vary significantly according to the financial calendar and where they live.<ref name="BMJ 2013;347:f6686">{{cite news|last=Kmietowicz|first=Zosia|title=Commissioners are restricting referrals for hip and knee surgery, says report|url=http://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6686|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=BMJ|date=6 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Denis|title=A&E overcrowding may cost lives, emergency doctors warn|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/nov/06/accident-emergency-overcrowding-costs-lives-doctors|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=6 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Patients must get fairer access to medical technology|url=http://www.theinformationdaily.com/2013/11/07/patients-must-get-fairer-access-to-medical-technology|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=The Information Daily|date=7 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Patients facing hip-knee 'lottery'|url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/patients-facing-hip-knee-lottery-002251392.html#7ZSqPZ5|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=Yahoo News (via Press Association)|date=6 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Patients facing hip-knee 'lottery'|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/patients-facing-hipknee-lottery-8923627.html#.UnoSnHyMtrw.email|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=London Evening Standard|date=6 November 2013}}</ref>
=== <small>Work Foundation report</small> ===
In November 2011, [[The Work Foundation]] published a report, ''Adding Value: The Economic and Societal Benefits of Medical Technology'',<ref>http://www.theworkfoundation.com/DownloadPublication/Report/296_Adding%20value%20-%20The%20Economic%20and%20Societal%20Benefits%20of%20Medical%20Technology.pdf</ref> funded by a research grant from the MTG. The report, which was launched in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], identified three key areas of benefits from medical technologies:<ref>{{cite web|title=Work Foundation Report – Adding value: The Economic and Societal Benefits of Medical Technology|url=https://www.boa.ac.uk/About/CEOBlog/Lists/Posts/Post.aspx?ID=94|publisher=British Orthopaedic Association|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Rennard|first=Lord|title=The long term benefits of medical technology must be recognised|url=http://centrallobby.politicshome.com/latestnews/article-detail/newsarticle/the-long-term-benefits-of-medical-technologies-must-be-recognised/|newspaper=Politics Home|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
* Improvements in health care (quality, efficiency and the empowerment of patients); * Improving quality of life and independent living (reducing fears and anxiety, increasing flexibility, and reducing the need for informal care and the burden on informal caregivers); * Labour market participation and productivity (increasing labour market participation, retaining skills and improving productivity).
=== <small>Uterine artery/fibroid embolisation (UFE)</small> ===
In 2011 the MTG and patient support group FEmISA published a report, ''The provision of and access to Uterine Artery/Fibroid'',<ref>http://www.mtg.org.uk/files/UFEResearchReport.pdf</ref> a less invasive treatment for [[fibroma|fibroids]] for women. The report, which was welcomed by the British Society of Interventional Radiologists, highlighted a lack of coherent commissioning in England, despite [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] clinical guidelines recommending UFE as a first line treatment for symptomatic fibroids.<ref>{{cite web|title=Significant variation in numbers of women in England undergoing uterine fibroid embolisation to treat fibroids|url=http://www.rightcare.nhs.uk/index.php/2011/10/significant-variation-ufe/|publisher=Right Care|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Your first choice: the provision of and access to UFE|url=http://kingsfund.blogs.com/health_management/2011/10/your-first-choice-the-provision-of-and-access-to-ufe.html|publisher=The King's Fund|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
=== <small>Insulin pump provision</small> ===
In 2010 the MTG made a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information]] request to [[NHS Primary Care Trust|Primary Care Trusts]] in England on the provision of insulin pumps to patients with [[Type 1 diabetes]]. It found the average to be 3.9 per cent compared to the 12 per cent benchmark recommended by the [[National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence]]. The findings were the subject of an [[Early Day Motion]] tabled by [[Adrian Sanders|Adrian Sanders MP]] on December 9, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Early day motion 1167|url=http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2010-12/1167|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref>
=== <small>Medical technology</small> ===
In 2004, the MTG's report Making the Economic Case for Medical Technology suggested that increasing the provision of medical technology can "help patients better manage their conditions" and lead a "longer and relatively healthy life".<ref>http://www.patientsorganizations.org/attach.pl/290/69/Economic%20Benefits%20of%20Medical%20Technology%20-%20MTG,%20June%202004.pdf</ref> It also suggested that by making greater use of technology there are cost benefits for [[National Health Service|the National Health Service]]. The report was the subject of an Early Day Motion tabled by [[Ian Gibson (politician)|Ian Gibson MP]]. The motion was signed by 30 [[Members of Parliament]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Early day motion 1865|url=http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2003-04/1865|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref>
== Organisation ==
The MTG is chaired by Barbara Harpham, National Director of [[Heart Research UK]]. She has been quoted as saying that the UK lags behind other European countries in the take-up of medical technology.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fear of cuts to NHS medical technology budgets|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/8374275.stm|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=25 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=NHS 'must boost use of technology' or risk falling behind|url=http://www.nursingtimes.net/whats-new-in-nursing/news-topics/health-informatics/nhs-must-boost-use-of-technology-or-risk-falling-behind/5008942.article|accessdate=25 November 2013|newspaper=Nursing Times|date=25 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Five minutes with ... the chair of the Medical Technology Group|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2014/feb/07/barbara-harpham-medical-technology-group|accessdate=2 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 February 2014}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|last1=Nigel|first1=Hawkes|title=The Times|url=http://raconteur.net/healthcare/uk-lags-behind-rest-of-europe-with-latest-heart-treatments|accessdate=15 October 2015|publisher=Raconteur|date=8 October 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

page.title: Mental health in the Middle East

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{cleanup|date=April 2013|reason=The logical flow of ideas needs to be improved}} {{more footnotes|date=April 2013}} }} The study of '''mental health in the Middle East''' is an area of [[research]] that continues to grow in its scope and content.{{cite news|title=Mental health and psychiatry in the Middle East: historical development|author=A. Mohit|journal=Eastern Mediterranean Health Journal|volume=7|number=3|year=2001|pages=336–347}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emro.who.int/publications/emhj/0703/2Mental.htm|title=WHO EMRO - Volume 7, issue 3 - EMHJ volume 7, 2001 - Eastern Mediterranean Health Journal|first=|last=emhj|website=www.emro.who.int}} In 1998, the World Mental Health Survey Initiative{{cite web|url=http://www.hcp.med.harvard.edu/wmh/|title=The World Mental Health Survey Initiative|website=www.hcp.med.harvard.edu}} was conducted by the [[World Federation for Mental Health]]. The (WFMH) was originally created in 1948 and works in concert with the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO). The 1998 [[Statistical survey|survey]] sought to help define and clarify [[mental health]] Issues across many [[societies]]. [[File:ReligionSymbolAbr.PNG|thumb|125px|right|Symbols of the three main [[Abrahamic religions]] – [[Judaism]], [[Christianity]], and [[Islam]]]] To accurately evaluate and understand the mental health issues of the [[Middle East]], one must take into account the [[geography|geographic]], [[history|historical]], [[culture|cultural]], and social influences of that part of the world. While each of the many countries commonly considered part of the "Middle East" is unique, there is a binding [[ethnic]] fabric that should be considered. Firstly, the Middle East is the origin of many of the major world [[religions]]. [[Christianity]], [[Judaism]] and [[Islam]], all began in this region. Of these many religions, Islam has had the most lasting and [[cultural]]ly significant influence on the region, encompassing well over ninety percent (90%) of the [[population]] by some measurements. The tenets of the [[Islamic faith]], and its strict purpose, certainly have served as both a guide and a hindrance to the practices' of [[mental health care]] providers in the Middle East. There is a conflict between ancient religious teachings and the modern day or "[[Western world]]" approach to the issues of mental health. {{Infobox | bodyclass = geography | above = Middle East | image = [[File:Map-Region-Middle-East.png|250px|Middle East]] | label1 = Countries | data1 = 18–38 ''(varying definitions)'' | label2 = Languages | data2 = '''Middle East:''' [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Neo-Aramaic languages|Aramaic]], [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[French language|French]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]]
'''Greater Middle East:''' [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]], [[Balochi language|Balochi]], [[Dari (Eastern Persian)|Dari]], [[French language|French]], [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Georgian language|Georgian]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Somali language|Somali]], [[Tamazight]], [[Tigrinya language|Tigrinya]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Urdu]] | label3 = Time Zones | data3 = UTC +8:00 (China) to UTC +3:30 (Iran) | label4 = Largest Cities | data4 = In rank order: [[Cairo]], [[Tehran]], [[Baghdad]], [[Riyadh]], [[Jeddah]] }} ==Historical perspective== [[Mental health]] in the [[Middle East]], from [[Pharaonic]] times through to the [[Islamic Renaissance]], has a rich and complex history. During Pharaonic times, [[wikt:soma|soma]] and [[Psyche (psychology)|psyche]] were terms used to define [[mental disorders]], and such disorders were described as problems of the [[heart]] or [[uterus]], as stated in Eber's and Kahoun's Papyri.{{cite book|url=http://www.wrf.org/ancient-medicine/oldest-medical-books.php|title=Magic and Medical Science in Ancient Egypt|year=1963|author=Ghalioungui, Paul}} While [[mystical]] culture predominated at that time, mental disorders were treated on a [[Somatic symptom disorder|somatic]] basis. In the [[Islamic]] era, those with mental illness were not known to have endured any forms of [[torture]], nor were they [[ostracism|ostracized]]; this was due to the belief that [[Spirit possession|possession]] by a good Muslim [[genie]] was possible. The first [[mental hospital]] in [[Europe]] was located in [[Spain]], as discussed by author [[Paul Ghalioungui]], following the [[Moorish invasions]]. Mental hospitals then expanded to other European countries. The occurrence of [[anxiety]], [[schizophrenia]], [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[suicide]], [[conversion disorders]], and [[obsessive compulsive disorders]] had been reported, and these disorders were treated with some success.{{cite web|url=http://mentalillness.umwblogs.org/ancient-egypt/|title=Ancient Egypt - Treatment of the Mentally Ill|website=mentalillness.umwblogs.org}} [[Morality]] and [[culture]] most likely arose from a [[collective]] choice of [[communal]] decisions to provide an accepted structure of communal living. [[Geography]], [[tradition]], and the specific [[environment (biophysical)|environment]] may have been most influential in these decisions.{{clarify|date=April 2013|reason=what decisions, exactly?}} The development or evolution of a [[Social environment|social milieu]] integrated with the culmination of culture.{{clarify|date=April 2013|reason=the previous sentence does not make sense}} Cultural [[morality]] has provided a way of managing [[conflict (process)|conflict]] within a societal group. Cultural morality and the required [[behaviors]] that are cooperative in nature and a cognizance of others within the group, ostracized [[unhealthy]] behaviors, and therefore encouraged [[emotions]] and actions beneficial to [[society]]. These realized constructs provided an outlet and model of [[motivation]]s and accepted actions within a [[social group]].D. Wong, "Natural Moralities," (October 2006), Oxford University Press, 2006 [abs]. In a 1992 study,[http://www.subjectpool.com/ed_teach/y4person/7_creativity/2010/2PersonalityAndValues.pptx Personality and Values] (PPT) Schwartz, Roccas and Sagiv evaluated how priorities are displayed and altered by a "social experience",{{cite journal | pmid = 11927158 | volume=109 | title=Social experience and social context alter the behavioral response to centrally administered oxytocin in female Syrian hamsters | journal=Neuroscience | pages=767–72 | last1 = Harmon | first1 = AC | last2 = Moore | first2 = TO | last3 = Huhman | first3 = KL | last4 = Albers | first4 = HE | doi=10.1016/s0306-4522(01)00523-1}} and how those priorities affect "behavioral orientation and choices".{{cite journal | last1 = Schwartz | first1 = Shalom H | year = 1992 | title = Universals in the Content and Structure of Values: Theoretical Advances and Empirical Tests in 20 Countries | url = | journal = Advances in Experimental Social Psychology | volume = 25 | issue = | pages = 1–65 }} The study surmised that the majority of cultures prioritize some of ten particular [[values|value]] types: [[self-determination]], [[stimulation]], [[hedonism]], [[accomplishment|achievement]], [[power (philosophy)|power]], [[security]], [[conformity]], [[tradition]], [[altruism|benevolence]], and [[universalism]].{{cite web|url=http://changingminds.org/explanations/values/schwartz_inventory.htm|title=Schwartz's Value Inventory|website=changingminds.org}} Among these there were [[values]] that [[culture]]s prioritize to varying degrees.{{clarify|date=April 2013|reason=This whole paragraph needs a rewrite, because it doesn't make any sense}} Schwartz used these findings in developing his [[theory]] of specific types of [[values]], allowing varying cultures to be contrasted with one another. Data was collected from 49 countries and applied to a [[construct (philosophy of science)|construct]] of seven value types. This was done according to the specific priority given by a society to its [[communal]] value set. Schwartz selected the seven types of values based on their compatibilities and [[contradiction]]s to one another. The value types he identified were: "[[conservatism]] vs. [[autonomy]]", "[[hierarchy]] vs. [[egalitarianism]]", and "[[mastery]] vs. [[harmony]]".{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0065260108602816|title=Universals in the Content and Structure of Values: Theoretical Advances and Empirical Tests in 20 Countries|journal=Advances in Experimental Social Psychology|date=1 January 1992|publisher=Academic Press|volume=25|pages=1–65|citeseerx=10.1.1.220.3674|doi=10.1016/S0065-2601(08)60281-6|author= Schwartz, Shalom H.}} The [[value (personal and cultural)|value types]] were then used to examine [[culture]]s that were closely related to each other. The theory is based on [[cultural]] dimensions so that conclusions can be defined to a degree, while accounting for the entire social matrix.{{clarify|date=April 2013|reason=The meaning of this sentence is unclear}} This theory has helped [[researchers]] to assess the cultural implications of values on regional cultures. The research also found a [[correlation]] between geographical proximity and shared cultural values. Schwartz attributed these relationships to the "shared [[history]]", [[religion]], level of development, culture contact, and other factors".{{cite web|author=Shwartz, S.|year=1999|url=http://www.sjsu.edu/people/sharon.glazer/courses/psyc190/s1/Schwartz+1999.pdf|title=A theory of cultural values and some implications for work|volume=48|issue=1|pp=23–47|journal=Applied Psychology: An International Review|publisher=International association of applied psychology|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626115004/http://www.sjsu.edu/people/sharon.glazer/courses/psyc190/s1/Schwartz%201999.pdf|archivedate=26 June 2011}} ==Known syndromes== ===Zār=== [[Zār]]{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/zar|title=ZĀR – Encyclopaedia Iranica|first=|last=electricpulp.com|website=www.iranicaonline.org}}[http://homepage.mac.com/mccajor/cbs_glos.html TMH: Glossary of Culture-Bound Syndromes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526131405/http://homepage.mac.com/mccajor/cbs_glos.html |date=2010-05-26 }} (زار) known as [[Demonic possession|possession]] by a [[spirit]], is exhibited by some Middle Eastern cultures.[http://www.culturediversity.org/mide.htm Middle Eastern] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725214245/http://www.culturediversity.org/mide.htm |date=2011-07-25 }} Specific ceremonies are performed to placate the zār and relieve the symptoms of the afflicted individual. These [[ritual]]ized ceremonies, organized and facilitated by a leader, include the affected individual and a person previously affected by the zār, and involve "[[incense]], music, and movement". The details of the [[ceremony]] vary by region. Some leaders may recommend that the [[patient]] first seek the help of a [[Physician|doctor]], while others believe that interventions by the doctor, such as using needles for injections, may further agitate the zār, creating more problems for the patient. Those who choose traditional treatment for zār remain in isolation for up to seven days. This [[syndrome]] has been reported in [[North Africa]]n and Middle Eastern countries, including [[Ethiopia]], [[Egypt]], [[Iran]], and [[Sudan]]. Signs and [[symptoms]] of zār may include [[dissociative state|dissociative]] episodes, unexpected laughing, yelling, or singing, or even patients hitting their heads against a wall. Clients may exhibit [[apathy]] and be [[reclusive]]. Those under the influence of the zār may refuse to eat or carry out [[activities of daily living]], and may develop an extended interaction with the possessing spirit. ===The evil eye=== [[File:Ruby Eye Pendant.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Corundum]] Evil Eye [[Amulet]] from [[Mesapotamia]] ʘDanieliness{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Danieliness|title=User:Danieliness - Wikimedia Commons|website=commons.wikimedia.org}}]] The "[[evil eye]]" is also known as ʿayn al-ḥasūd (عين الحسود)" and "Mal De Ojo", and has been described by a number of sources. It is also described in [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[culture]][http://altmed.creighton.edu/MexicanFolk/mal_de_ojo.htm Mal de ojo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719181959/http://altmed.creighton.edu/MexicanFolk/mal_de_ojo.htm |date=2011-07-19 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.sfbardo.com/maldeojo.htm|title=Evil Eye - Mal de Ojo|website=www.sfbardo.com}}Dundes A, "Interpreting Folklore," Indiana University Press, Ed.,(1980)Dundes A"The Evil Eye: A Casebook." [[University of Wisconsin]] Press, Ed.,1992. The late Professor [[Alan Dundes]] theorized that belief in the evil eye had a [[Middle Eastern]], [[Mediterranean]], and [[Indo European]] pattern of distribution, and was completely unknown in the [[Americas]], [[Pacific Islands]], [[Asia]], and [[sub-Saharan Africa]] until the introduction of European and possibly [[Moorish]] culture. He based his ideas upon the ancient underlying belief that water represented [[life]] and dryness represented [[death]]. Dundes suggested that evil caused by the evil eye came from its power to cause living beings to "dry up", specifically referring to infants, [[lactation|lactating]] [[mammal]]s, and even young fruit trees.Fables of the Ancients: Folklore in the Qur'an. Rowman & Littlefield,(2003) Symptoms included sudden [[vomiting]], [[diarrhea]], and loss of [[virility|potency]] in men. Dundes contended that the evil eye dries up liquids, which explained its Middle Eastern and [[desert]] origins. This unique [[syndrome]] is also mentioned in the [[DSM-IV TR]], Appendix I.^"Appendix I: Outline for Cultural Formulation and Glossary of Culture-Bound Syndromes". Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fourth Edition, Text Revision (DSM-IV-TR), 1. 2000. {{doi|10.1176/appi.books.9780890423349.7060}}. {{ISBN|0-89042-334-2}} The syndrome is also seen in many other [[Middle Eastern]] Countries.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} ===Post-traumatic stress syndrome=== [[Post-traumatic stress syndrome]] (PTSD) is, unfortunately, common in the Middle East due to the myriad conflicts experienced by people in the region.{{cite journal | url=https://www.ptsd.va.gov/professional/newsletters/research-quarterly/v21n4.pdf | title=Trauma and PTSD among Civilians in the Middle East | journal=PTSD Research Quarterly| volume =21|number= 4 |year=2010|author1=Yuval Neria|author2=Margarita Bravova|author3=Jessica M. Halper. }} Diagnostic symptoms for PTSD include recurrent experiencing of the initial [[Psychological trauma|trauma]]tic event(s) through [[Flashback (psychology)|flashback]]s or recurrent [[night sweats]] and [[nightmare]]s. Those afflicted with post-traumatic stress syndrome often seek to avoid others as well as any [[stimulus (psychology)|stimulus]] similar to the traumatic occurrence. They may also exhibit increased [[arousal]]. Difficulty in falling or staying asleep, unexpected episodic fits of [[anger]], and [[hypervigilance]] may also occur. The formal [[diagnostic criteria]] for both the [[DSM-IV-TR]] and [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems|ICD-10]]) indicate that symptoms last for more than one month and cause significant impairment in [[social functioning|social]], occupational, and/or other important areas of functioning.American Psychiatric Association (1994). Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders: DSM-IV. [[Washington, DC]]: American Psychiatric Association. {{ISBN|0-89042-061-0}}. There is also some evidence that children suffering from PTSD in the Middle East may experience accelerated aging.{{cite web|url=https://health.ucsd.edu/news/releases/pages/2015-05-07-ptsd-accelerates-aging.aspx|title=Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Linked to Accelerated Aging|work=UC Health - UC San Diego|date=May 7, 2015|author1=Scott LaFee|author2=Heather Buschman}} ===Depression=== [[Depression (mood)|Depression]] in the Middle East has been specifically studied at [[Namazi Hospital]] Shiraz, in Iran. In a 2006 study of nurses, depressive symptoms were seen in 26.9% of the individuals studied.{{cite web|url=http://www.mejfm.com/journal/july2006/Depression%20in%20nurses.htm|title=Middle East Journal of Family Medicine|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications/depression/complete-index.shtml|title=NIMH » Depression Basics|website=www.nimh.nih.gov}} In this [[cross-sectional survey]], the rate of depression in 130 nurses was investigated using the 21-item [[Beck Depression Inventory]].{{cite journal | last1 = Beck | first1 = AT | last2 = Ward | first2 = CH | last3 = Mendelson | first3 = M | last4 = Mock | first4 = J | last5 = Erbaugh | first5 = J | year = 1961 | title = An inventory for measuring depression | url = | journal = Arch. Gen. Psychiatry | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 561–71 | pmid = 13688369 | doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1961.01710120031004}} Data collection also involved individual interviews and follow-up by the research team.{{clarify|date=April 2013|reason=and found what?}} ==See also== * [[Cross-cultural psychiatry]] * [[Cultural competence]] * [[Culture-bound syndrome]] * [[Ethnocultural empathy]] * [[Global mental health]] * [[Mental health in China]] * [[Mental health in Southeast Africa]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== * {{Cite journal | last = Allan | first = Lyle | title = A selective annotated bibliography of multiculturalism | journal = Social Alternatives | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 65–72 | publisher = [[University of Queensland]] | date = July 1983 | url = http://socialalternatives.com/issues | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal | last1 = Arieli | first1 = A. | last2 = Aychen | first2 = S. | title = [Mental disease related to belief in being possessed by the "Zar" spirit] | journal = [[Harefuah]] | volume = 126 | issue = 11 | pages = 636–642 | publisher = [[Israel Medical Association]] | date = 1994 | pmid = 7926995 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{cite news | title = Revolution in Egypt's mental health care | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8034504.stm | work = [[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 6 May 2009 }} * Blainey, Geoffrey (1984), ''All For Australia'', Methuen Haynes, North Ryde, New South Wales, {{ISBN|0-454-00828-7}} * [http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=39380 Conflict behind rise in mental health disorders in Somalia], Middle East Online, IRIN, 2010-06-04 *{{cite journal |author=Brody EB |title=The World Federation for Mental Health: its origins and contemporary relevance to WHO and WPA policies |journal=World Psychiatry |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=54–5 |date=February 2004 |pmid=16633456 |pmc=1414666 }} * Clancy, Greg (2006), ''The Conspiracies of Multiculturalism'', Sunda Publications, Gordon, New South Wales. {{ISBN|0-9581564-1-7}} * {{Cite journal | last = Edelstein | first = Monika D. | title = Lost tribes and coffee ceremonies: ''Zar'' spirit possession and the ethno‐religious identity of Ethiopian Jews in Israel | journal = Journal of Refugee Studies | volume = 15 | issue = 2 | pages = 153–170 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | doi = 10.1093/jrs/15.2.153 | date = June 2002 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/jrs/15.2.153 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://www.weizmann.ac.il/home/liorg/zar.pdf Pdf.] * [http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/society Definition of Society] from the [[Oxford English Dictionary|OED]]. * Hirst, John (2005), ''Sense and Nonsense in Australian History'', Black Inc. Agenda, Melbourne, Victoria. {{ISBN|978-0-9775949-3-1}} * Keonig, H. revision.text:
[[Image:A thaliana metabolic network.png|thumb|240px|right|[[Metabolic network]] showing interactions between enzymes and metabolites in the ''[[Arabidopsis thaliana]]'' citric acid cycle. Enzymes and metabolites are the red dots and interactions between them are the lines.]] [[Image:Metabolic Network Model for Escherichia coli.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Metabolic network model for ''[[Escherichia coli]]''.]]
'''Metabolic network reconstruction and simulation''' allows for an in-depth insight into the molecular mechanisms of a particular organism. In particular, these models correlate the [[genome]] with molecular [[physiology]].<ref name=Franke_2005>{{cite journal|last=Franke|author2=Siezen, Teusink|title=Reconstructing the metabolic network of a bacterium from its genome.|journal=Trends in Microbiology|year=2005|volume=13|issue=11|pages=550–558|pmid=16169729|doi=10.1016/j.tim.2005.09.001}}</ref> A reconstruction breaks down [[metabolic]] pathways (such as [[glycolysis]] and the [[citric acid cycle]]) into their respective reactions and enzymes, and analyzes them within the perspective of the entire network. In simplified terms, a reconstruction collects all of the relevant metabolic information of an organism and compiles it in a mathematical model. Validation and analysis of reconstructions can allow identification of key features of metabolism such as growth yield, resource distribution, network robustness, and gene essentiality. This knowledge can then be applied to create novel [[biotechnology]].
In general, the process to build a reconstruction is as follows: # Draft a reconstruction # Refine the model # Convert model into a mathematical/computational representation # Evaluate and debug model through experimentation
==Genome-scale metabolic reconstruction== A metabolic reconstruction provides a highly mathematical, structured platform on which to understand the systems biology of metabolic pathways within an organism.<ref name=Thiele_2010>{{cite journal|last=Thiele|first=Ines|author2=Bernhard Ø Palsson|title=A protocol for generating a high-quality genome-scale metabolic reconstruction|journal=Nature Protocols|date=January 2010|volume=5|issue=1|pages=93–121|doi=10.1038/nprot.2009.203|pmid=20057383|pmc=3125167}}</ref> The integration of biochemical metabolic pathways with rapidly available, annotated genome sequences has developed what are called genome-scale metabolic models. Simply put, these models correspond metabolic genes with metabolic pathways. In general, the more information about physiology, biochemistry and genetics is available for the target organism, the better the predictive capacity of the reconstructed models. Mechanically speaking, the process of reconstructing prokaryotic and eukaryotic [[metabolic network]]s is essentially the same. Having said this, eukaryote reconstructions are typically more challenging because of the size of genomes, coverage of knowledge, and the multitude of cellular compartments.<ref name="Thiele_2010"/> The first genome-scale metabolic model was generated in 1995 for ''Haemophilus influenzae''.<ref name=Venter_Influenzae>{{cite journal|title=Whole-genome random sequencing and assembly of Haemophilus influenzae Rd|journal=Science|year=1995|volume=269|issue=1995|pages=496–512|pmid=7542800|doi=10.1126/science.7542800|author1=Fleischmann|first1=R. D.|last2=Adams|first2=M. D.|last3=White|first3=O|last4=Clayton|first4=R. A.|last5=Kirkness|first5=E. F.|last6=Kerlavage|first6=A. R.|last7=Bult|first7=C. J.|last8=Tomb|first8=J. F.|last9=Dougherty|first9=B. A.|last10=Merrick|first10=J. M.|bibcode=1995Sci...269..496F}}</ref> The first multicellular organism, ''C. elegans'', was reconstructed in 1998.<ref name="The1998">{{cite journal|author=The C. elegans Sequencing Consortium|journal=Science|volume=282|pages=2012–2018 |title=Genome Sequence of the Nematode C. elegans: A Platform for Investigating Biology |year=1998|doi=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012|issue=5396|pmid=9851916}}</ref> Since then, many reconstructions have been formed. For a list of reconstructions that have been converted into a model and experimentally validated, see http://sbrg.ucsd.edu/InSilicoOrganisms/OtherOrganisms.
