revision.text:
{{globalize|date=August 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2018}} [[File:Militärbiscuit gross klein.jpg|thumb|Militärbiscuits Standard packaging and Small packaging ]] [[File:Militärbiscuit gross klein offen.jpg|thumb|Open packaging]] The '''Military Biscuit''' ({{lang-de|Militärbiscuit}}; {{lang-fr| biscuits militaires}}; {{lang-it|biscotti militari}}; {{lang-rm|biscuits militars}};) is a food component of the Swiss army.
==History== Oscar J. Kambly, the second-generation boss of the traditional swiss company ''Kambly SA'', developed the recipe for flavor-neutral pastries in 1959. It was to replace the military [[Zwieback]] known as ''Bundesziegel'' in German language ([[Federation|federal]] [[Roof tiles|brick]]) and should be compatible with cheese or sausage as well as with chocolate. It should have a shelf life of at least three years. Since 1959, the army has distributed about a million servings of the military biscuits to the soldiers every year. The military biscuits are also popular by the civilian population of Switzerland.
Some private traders sold military biscuits, which the [[Federal Department of Defence, Civil Protection and Sport|DDPS]] initially wanted to prevent, because the trade with army food is forbidden. This is also noted on the packaging. Since 2010, Kambly, still a manufacturer of military biscuits, is allowed to sell these to large distributors. The packaging has to be different from the biscuits produced for the military.<ref>[http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/leben/essen-und-trinken/Der-Kult-ums-staubigste-Guetzli-/story/10317711 Der Kult ums staubigste Guetzli]</ref>
Since 2009, the biscuits have also been distributed together with the military chocolate in a gift box with the dedication of the [[Chief of the Armed Forces (Switzerland)|Chief of the Armed Forces]] to the soldiers who have fulfilled their military service obligations. 25,000 such gift boxes include the recurring yearly production for a year's release for the soldiers in Switzerland.
[[File:Militärbiscuits mit Verpackung.jpg|thumb|Smale Militärbiscuits Package and both sides]] In addition to the standard packaging, the Military Biscuit is also available as [[promotional merchandise]] with two pieces packed to a 9g small packaging.
==Ingredients and nutritional values== '''Ingredients''' *[[Wheat]] [[flour]], [[potato starch]], [[palm oil]], [[glucose]], [[sugar]], [[powdered milk]], [[malt]], [[leavening agent]], [[sodium hydrogencarbonate]], [[ammonium bicarbonate]], [[salt]].
'''Nutritional values per 100 grams''' *450 kilo [[Calorie]] *14 grams of fat *73 grams of carbohydrates *15 grams of which sugars *6.9 grams of protein *1.9 grams of salt
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.news.ch/Das+Militaer+Biscuit/652279/detail.htm ''Das Militär-Biscuit''.] * Adrian Schulthess, Antonia Sell: [http://www.blick.ch/news/schweiz/skandal-wieso-darf-volg-ploetzlich-militaer-biscuits-verkaufen-id81171.html ''Wieso darf Volg plötzlich Militär-Biscuits verkaufen?'' Why can Volg suddenly sell military biscuits?] In: ''[[Blick]]'', * [http://www.lba.admin.ch/internet/lba/de/home/themen/verpflegungsplanung/armeeproviant.html ''Armeeproviant. Militärbiscuit: Ein Klassiker – neu aufgelegt''.Armeeproviant. Military Biscuit: A classic - reissued] Website of the Logistikbasis der Armee.
{{Military of Switzerland}} {{Portal bar|War|Switzerland}}
[[Category:Military food]] [[Category:Military equipment of Switzerland]] [[Category:History of food and drink]] [[Category:Swiss cuisine]]

{{cleanup|reason=Not encyclopedic – an extended essay that only pilfers other sources, and has very poor ref usage.|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Sylvia Likens | image = File:Sylvia_Likens.jpg | image_upright = 0.65 | alt = | caption = Likens as she appeared prior to her stay at the Baniszewski residence | birth_name = Sylvia Marie Likens | birth_date = {{Birth date|1949|1|3}} | birth_place = [[Lebanon, Indiana]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1965|10|26|1949|1|3}} | death_place = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], U.S. | death_cause = {{Plainlist| * [[Cerebral hemorrhage]] * [[Shock (circulatory)|Shock]] * [[Malnutrition]] }} | resting_place = [[Oak Hill Cemetery (Lebanon, Indiana)|Oak Hill Cemetery]]
Lebanon, Indiana, U.S. | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|40|02|50|N|86|27|16|W|display=title}} | relatives = {{Plainlist| * Lester Cecil Likens (father) * Betty Likens (mother) * Daniel Likens (brother) * Diana Likens (sister) * Benny Ray Likens (brother) * {{nowrap|Jenny Fay Likens (sister)}} }} }} The '''murder of Sylvia Likens''' took place in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], United States in October 1965. The 16-year-old was held captive, [[Child abuse|abused]] and [[Torture murder|tortured to death]] over a period of three months by Gertrude Baniszewski, Baniszewski's children, and other neighborhood children. Likens' parents, who were [[Traveling carnival|carnival]] workers, had initially left her and her sister Jenny in the care of the Baniszewski family, paying Gertrude $20 a week to care for the sisters. Baniszewski, her daughter Paula, her son John, and two neighborhood youths, Coy Hubbard and Richard Hobbs, were tried and convicted of torturing and [[Child murder|murdering]] Likens. The case was described by the prosecutor in Baniszewski's trial as "the most terrible crime ever committed in the state of Indiana".[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,835635,00.html Avenging Sylvia]; ''Time Magazine'', 27 May 1966 ==Backgrounds== ===Gertrude Baniszewski=== '''Gertrude Nadine Baniszewski''' ({{nee|'''Van Fossan'''}}; September 19, 1929 – June 16, 1990) was born in Indianapolis, Indiana to Mollie Myrtle (''née'' Oakley) and Hugh Marcus Van Fossan Sr., both of whom were originally from [[Illinois]] and were of [[Americans|American]] and [[Dutch people|Dutch]] descent. Baniszewski was the third of six children. On October 5, 1939, Baniszewski witnessed her 50-year-old father's death from a sudden heart attack. Six years later, she dropped out of school to marry 18-year-old John Stephan Baniszewski (1926–2007), who was originally from [[Youngsville, Pennsylvania]], with whom she had six children. Although John Baniszewski had a volatile temper, the two stayed together for ten more years before divorcing. Baniszewski, then 34, moved in with 22-year-old Dennis Lee Wright, who abused her. She had one child with Dennis, Dennis Lee Wright Jr. (later given the name Denny Lee Wright by his adoptive mother), but after his birth, Wright abandoned Gertrude.{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/2.html|title=truTV - Funny Because it's tru|website=truTV|access-date=2016-09-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016070750/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/2.html|archive-date=2013-10-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Sylvia Likens=== '''Sylvia Marie Likens''' (January 3, 1949 – October 26, 1965) was the third child of [[Carny|carnival workers]] Lester Cecil Likens (1926–2013) and his wife Elizabeth Frances "Betty" (née Grimes, 1927–1998). She was born between two sets of fraternal [[twin]]s: Diana and Danny (two years older), and Jenny and Benny (one year younger, the former disabled by [[Poliomyelitis|polio]]).[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,901828,00.html Addenda to De Sade]; ''Time Magazine'', 6 May 1966 Likens' parents' marriage was unstable. The family moved frequently, and the parents had financial difficulties. Likens and her sister Jenny were often boarded out or forced to live with relatives, such as their grandmother, so that their schoolwork would not suffer while their parents were on the road.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/3.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: Foster Care] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080825083251/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/3.html |date=2008-08-25 }}; Crime Library.com To earn money, Likens babysat and ironed, the same kind of work that was done by Gertrude Baniszewski. At the time of Likens' death, her favorite rock band was [[The Beatles]].{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=kLG4NQn0yfQC&pg=PT36&lpg=PT36&dq=Memorial+Baptist+Church+sylvia+likens&source=bl&ots=b7s7j_Pkzw&sig=2KWFo_DLm67dUl2gi640-scvsbg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_x47YxJzWAhWFy7wKHaCNCDQQ6AEINzAC#v=onepage&q=Memorial%20Baptist%20Church%20sylvia%20likens&f=false|title=House of Evil: The Indiana Torture Slaying|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} In July 1965, Sylvia and Jenny Likens were living with their mother, Betty, in Indianapolis. During that time, Betty was arrested and jailed for [[shoplifting]]. Lester Likens, who had recently separated from his wife, arranged for his daughters to board with Gertrude Baniszewski, the mother of the girls' new friend Paula Baniszewski (aged 17) and Paula's six siblings, Stephanie (15), John (12), Marie (11), Shirley (10), James (8), and few-months-old Dennis Lee Wright Jr. During her early time with the Baniszewski family, she would sing with Baniszewski's daughter, Stephanie.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/4.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: Foster Care] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601215939/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/4.html |date=2009-06-01 }}; Crime Library.com Although the Baniszewskis were poor, Lester "didn't pry" into the condition of the house (as he reported at the trial), and he encouraged Baniszewski to "straighten his daughters out."[http://www2.indystar.com/library/factfiles/crime/history/likens_sylvia/sylvia.html The murder of Sylvia Likens] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010807200635/http://www.indystar.com/library/factfiles/crime/history/likens_sylvia/sylvia.html |date=2001-08-07 }}; ''Indianapolis Star'', Library Factfiles. ==Abuse and death== Lester Likens agreed to pay Baniszewski $20 a week in exchange for her care of the Likens girls. Baniszewski, described by ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'' as a "haggard, underweight [[asthma]]tic", was suffering from [[Major depressive disorder|depression]] and the stress of several failed marriages. When the weekly payment arrived late, Baniszewski beat the Likens girls on their bare buttocks with paddles. Baniszewski soon focused her [[child abuse|abuse]] exclusively on Sylvia. She accused her of stealing candy that she had bought, and humiliated her when she admitted that she once had a boyfriend. Baniszewski's daughter, Paula, who was pregnant at the time, kicked Likens in the genitals and accused her of being pregnant. Later medical examination proved that Likens was not pregnant and could not have been.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/5.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: A Dubious Start] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912111536/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/5.html |date=2008-09-12 }}; Crime Library.com Baniszewski began allowing her older children to beat Likens and repeatedly push her down stairs for entertainment. During a church function, Baniszewski [[Force-feeding|force-fed]] Likens a [[hot dog]] overloaded with condiments. Likens vomited afterwards, which she was later forced to consume. Baniszewski also accused Likens of [[prostitution]] and delivered [[Misogyny|misogynistic]] sermons about the filthiness of prostitutes and women in general. Likens was later accused of spreading rumors within [[Arsenal Technical High School]] that Paula and Stephanie Baniszewski were prostitutes. This supposedly provoked Stephanie's boyfriend, Coy Hubbard, to physically attack Likens. Hubbard and his classmates soon made frequent visits to the Baniszewski residence to torment Likens, often collaborating with Bansizewski's own children and Baniszewski herself. With Baniszewski's encouragement, they routinely beat her{{Cite book|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|publisher=Borf Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=38}}, forced her to eat feces and drink urine, used her as a practice dummy in violent [[judo]] sessions{{Cite web|url=http://www.indianapolismonthly.com/features/looking-back-indianas-infamous-crime-50-years-later/|title=Looking Back On Indiana's Most Infamous Crime, 50 Years Later|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}, lacerated her, burnt her body with lit cigarettes over 100 times{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/justice-story/teen-girl-fatally-bullied-indiana-house-horrors-article-1.1309751|title=Teen girl fatally bullied in Indiana house of horrors|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2017-08-04|language=en}} and severely injured her genitals{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=PAw1JRwc2zsC&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=sylvia+likens+mauling&source=bl&ots=GmGSvm_dYp&sig=3-BNwkDBPlm0lQBoSFJ6blvfd_A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijhc61muPXAhVGErwKHY6mCAUQ6AEIcTAP#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20mauling&f=false|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}}. To entertain Gertrude and her teenage accomplices, Likens was forced to strip naked in the living room and insert an empty Coca-Cola bottle into her own vagina.{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=fOQxIMXq35sC&pg=PR16&lpg=PR16&dq=sylvia+likens+masturbate&source=bl&ots=RHokquSaYH&sig=-W1vEH9TaPhi2Xx0-Gq8YIOOmRQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj84ILu6d3YAhXBopQKHemdAtUQ6AEITzAK#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20masturbate&f=false|title=House of Evil: The Indiana Torture Slaying|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} Paula Baniszewski once beat Likens in the face with such force that she broke her own wrist. She later had to wear a cast, which she used to further beat Likens.{{cite web|url=http://sylvialikens.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=177&sid=0be6b27a888f78f72360647d85b4b093|title=Jenny Fay Likens - Sister of Deceased - Sylvia Likens|website=sylvialikens.com}}{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=eONxCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=sylvia+likens+beaten+with+cast&source=bl&ots=7-werp-P_L&sig=PMyFIdvOAIDl2BNcGJXM7j-bkc4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjVtd-khprWAhXFwrwKHVZQCQMQ6AEIWDAH#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20beaten%20with%20cast&f=false|title=World Encyclopedia of 20th Century Murder|last=R. Nash|first=Jay|date=|website=|access-date=}} Gertrude Baniszewski later forced Jenny to hit her sister, beating her if she did not comply.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/7.html "The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917053831/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/7.html |date=2008-09-17 }} Crime Library. Meanwhile, Raymond and Phyllis Vermillion, a middle-aged couple who moved next door, saw Gertrude to be an ideal caretaker for their two children. They visited the Baniszewski residence on two occasions, where they witnessed Paula, with Gertrude's approval, abusing Likens and boasting about it in front of them. The Vermillions refused to report the abuse to the authorities out of fear on both occasions. {{Cite web|url=http://www.sylvialikens.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=173|title=Phyllis Vermillion - Next Door Neighbor|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Baniszewski eventually forbade Likens from attending school after Likens confessed to having stolen a gym suit from the school when Baniszewski would not buy a gym suit for her. She brutally beat and whipped Sylvia and did the same for Jenny after remembering that she supposedly stole a tennis shoe. Baniszewski then switched the topic to the "evils" of premarital sex and brutally kicked Sylvia repeatedly in the genitals. She also burned all of her fingers with matches and further whipped her.{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=PAw1JRwc2zsC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=sylvia+likens+gym+suit&source=bl&ots=GmGVvnS7Um&sig=WTIum4elXzljW-EsdKm3G49sWvc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPqKqsx7rYAhUKe7wKHRdDBq4Q6AEIZDAP#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20gym%20suit&f=false|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} Likens eventually became [[Urinary incontinence|incontinent]] due to the severity of the torture.{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=kLG4NQn0yfQC&pg=PT64&lpg=PT64&dq=sylvia+likens+incontinent+house+of+evil&source=bl&ots=b7t7l5RjEw&sig=0tzn0Z2Pfp3iwl56pA-2U5PUlpI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjS_MnXvsfYAhVMmJQKHefRBcYQ6AEIZDAM#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20incontinent%20house%20of%20evil&f=false|title=House of Evil: The Indiana Torture Slaying|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} She was denied access to the bathroom and so was forced to wet herself. As punishment for her incontinence, Baniszewski threw her in the basement and locked her in. Throughout her captivity, Baniszewski frequently, with the assistance of her children and their friends, restrained Likens in a bathtub filled with scalding water and rubbed salt onto her burns.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sylvialikens.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=177|title=Jenny Fay Likens - Sister of Deceased|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} She was often kept naked and rarely fed. At times, Baniszewski and her twelve-year-old son John Jr. would make Likens eat her own feces, as well as urine and feces from the diaper of Gertrude Baniszewski's one-year-old son. She also made abusing Likens a pastime, charging the neighborhood children five cents to see the "display" of Likens' naked body and tie, beat, burn and mutilate her. Likens attempted to alert the neighbors for help by screaming and hitting the walls of the basement with a spade, ultimately to no avail. The Likens sisters had no way to contact other family members to inform them of the abuse. Jenny, especially, struggled to do this since she was constantly threatened by Baniszewski that she would be abused and tortured next like her sister. She was also [[Bullying|bullied]] by the neighborhood girls and beaten whenever she alluded to Sylvia's situation. Nonetheless, they encountered Diana, their older and married sister, at the local park. Since Diana was forbidden by her parents to make contact with the sisters due to her estrangement, she initially assumed that the punishments Sylvia and Jenny were receiving were related to this. Neither party was aware that they lived less than a mile and a half apart. Diana eventually learned that Sylvia and Jenny were staying at a strangers' home and she attempted to visit them. Upon her visit, Bansizewski told Diana, unaware of who Baniszewski was, that the Likens sisters were not allowed to see her and ordered her off her property. At one point, Diana secretly gave a starving Sylvia a sandwich. Sylvia remained silent about the matter but after Marie Baniszewski revealed it, Paula and Gertrude choked and paddled Sylvia before subjecting her to another scalding bath. Shortly thereafter, a neighbor made an anonymous report, which prompted an in-home visit by a public health nurse. The nurse entered the home and made inquiries, but had no choice but to leave without further investigation. She told Baniszewski the report was about Likens; Baniszewski replied she had kicked Likens out of her house, and that her whereabouts were unknown. The nurse had no way of knowing that the subject of her inquiry was right below her in the basement. Likens was often deprived of water. Jenny later speculated, during her court testimony, that Likens was unable to produce tears due to [[dehydration]]. On October 22, Likens was forced by John to eat a bowl of soup with her fingers. John quickly took away the bowl when Likens attempted to eat it. Baniszewski eventually allowed her to sleep upstairs, under the condition that she learned not to wet herself. That night, Likens whispered to Jenny to give her a glass of water before falling asleep. {{Cite book|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|publisher=Borf Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=61}}On October 23, Baniszewski discovered that Likens had urinated herself. As punishment, Likens was forced to masturbate with an empty glass Coca-Cola bottle in front of Baniszewski's children. After that, she stripped Likens naked and [[Human branding|carved]] the words "I'M A PROSTITUTE AND PROUD OF IT" onto Likens' abdomen with a heated needle.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19651028&id=ZgYrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NZgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6404,6841839&hl=en|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=PAw1JRwc2zsC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=sylvia+likens+whipping&source=bl&ots=GmGToqZfVh&sig=drMzugkCi-YaYiR60-NR5kUjptI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY8sXyie3XAhWLp5QKHb8LC7gQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=october%2022&f=false|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} When Baniszewski was unable to finish the branding, she had Richard Hobbs finish. Hobbs continued to brand Likens as Baniszewski calmly took Jenny to the groceries. {{Cite book|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|publisher=Borf Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=63}}Hobbs and 10-year-old Shirley Baniszewski then used an [[Fire iron|iron poker]] in an attempt to burn the letter "S" into Likens' chest; the burn scar ended up looking like the number "3."[http://www.sylvialikens.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=177&sid=2d539eaab9268eeaf90fd1f33a10776d] Jenny Fay Likens Baniszewski later taunted Likens about how she would never be able to marry a man due to the words carved onto her stomach. Likens was taken back to the basement, where Coy Hubbard arrived to tie her up and slam her body against the walls six to seven times. That night, Likens confided to her sister, "I'm going to die. I can tell". {{Cite book|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|publisher=Borf Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=65}}The next day, Baniszewski woke Likens, then dictated a letter to her, intending to mislead her parents into believing that she had run away. The letter also tried to frame a group of anonymous boys for abusing and mutilating Likens after she supposedly agreed to have sexual relations with them. After Likens finished the letter, Baniszewski formulated a plan to have John Jr. and Jenny take Sylvia to a nearby forested area and leave her there to die. On October 25, Likens tried to escape after overhearing Baniszewski's plan to blindfold her and dump her body in Jimmy's Forest, a wooded area nearby. Likens fled to the front door but due to her extensive injuries, Baniszewski caught her in time. Likens was provided with toast but was unable to eat it due to her severe dehydration. Baniszewski shoved the toast into her mouth and struck her face several times with a curtain rod. She violently threw Likens into the basement and with the assistance of Hubbard, she tied and bludgeoned her until she was unconscious. Likens managed to recover but was unable to speak intelligibly and move her limbs properly. Likens tried to exit the basement but collapsed before she could make it to the stairs. Baniszewski crushed her head with her feet and stood there for several moments. {{Cite book|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|publisher=Borf Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=71}} On October 26, after multiple beatings, burnings, and scalding baths, Likens died of a [[Intracerebral hemorrhage|brain hemorrhage]], [[Shock (circulatory)|shock]], and [[malnutrition]]. She was 16 years old. When Stephanie Baniszewski and Richard Hobbs realized that Likens was not breathing, Stephanie tried to give her [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|mouth-to-mouth resuscitation]]. Banzisewski, however, shouted at them that Likens was "faking it".{{Cite web|url=http://www.sylvialikens.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=135|title=Richard Hobbs - Defendant|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} When Baniszewski finally realized that Likens was dead, she sent Hobbs to call the police from a nearby [[payphone]]. When police arrived, Gertrude Baniszewski handed them the letter she had forced Likens to write a few days previously. Before the police officers left the house, however, Jenny Likens approached them and said, "Get me out of here and I'll tell you everything."[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/13.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: The Letter Before End] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080824165415/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/13.html |date=2008-08-24 }}; Crime Library.com Her statement, combined with the discovery of Likens' body, prompted the officers to arrest Gertrude, Paula, Stephanie and John Baniszewski, Richard Hobbs, and Coy Hubbard for murder. Other neighborhood children present at the time—Mike Monroe, Randy Lepper, Darlene McGuire, Judy Duke, and Anna Siscoe—were arrested for "injury to person". ==Trial== [[File:Jenny Fay Likens.jpg|thumb|Jenny Likens watching the proceedings of the Baniszewski trial. She instigated the investigation and the subsequent arrest of her sister's torturers and murderers.]] Baniszewski, her children, Hobbs, and Hubbard were held without bail pending their trials. An examination and autopsy of Likens' body revealed numerous burns, bruising, muscle and nerve damage. All of her fingernails were also broken backwards and most of the skin's outer layer peeled off. Her severely mutilated body led authorities to initially believe that it was the work of an "anonymous madman".{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=PAw1JRwc2zsC&pg=PA12&lpg=PA12&dq=sylvia+likens+autopsy+madman&source=bl&ots=GmFWmlW7Uh&sig=6hLu6CWNFGw57Ko9l_aoXYzGUKA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZsMys-5nWAhXHzbwKHXp1DPIQ6AEIUjAG#v=onepage&q=sylvia%20likens%20autopsy%20madman&f=false|title=The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens' Ordeal and Death|last=Dean|first=John|date=|website=|access-date=}} In her death throes, Likens bit through her lips, partially severing each of them. Her vaginal cavity was nearly swollen shut, although an examination of the canal determined that her [[hymen]] was still intact, which meant it was possible she was still a virgin, discrediting Baniszewski's assertions that Likens was a prostitute and her insistence that she was pregnant. The official cause of death was brain swelling, internal hemorrhaging of the brain, and shock from severe and prolonged damage to her skin. During the highly publicized trial, Gertrude Baniszewski denied being responsible for Likens' death. She pleaded [[Insanity defense|not guilty by reason of insanity]]. She claimed that she was too distracted by her ill health and [[Depression (mood)|depression]] to control her children. Four minors who took part in the abuse of Likens were also put on trial. They were: *Paula Baniszewski, aged 17 *John Baniszewski, aged 13 *Richard Hobbs, aged 15 *Coy Hubbard, aged 15 The attorneys for the minors claimed that they had been pressured by Baniszewski. When Gertrude's 11-year-old daughter, Marie Baniszewski, was called to the stand as a witness for the defense, she broke down and admitted that she had been forced to heat the needle with which Hobbs had carved Likens' skin. She also testified that she had seen her mother beating Likens and forcing her into the basement. In his closing statement, Baniszewski's lawyer said: "I condemn her for being a murderess ... but I say she's not responsible because she's not all here!" He tapped his head to make his point about her state of mind.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/16.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: Drama in the Court Room] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080824121151/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/16.html |date=2008-08-24 }}; Crime Library.com On May 19, 1966, Gertrude Baniszewski was convicted of first-degree [[murder]]. She was spared the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]] and was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]]. Paula Baniszewski, who had given birth to a daughter during the trial, was convicted of second-degree murder. She was also sentenced to life imprisonment. Richard Hobbs, Coy Hubbard, and John Baniszewski Jr. were all convicted of [[manslaughter]] and given two 2-to-21-year prison sentences. ==Aftermath== Hobbs, Hubbard, and John Baniszewski Jr. each served two years in a reformatory before being paroled in 1968.Unnamed author: "150 Hear Likens Case Sentences," ''The Indianapolis News,'' May 25, 1966[http://www.indystar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/99999999/NEWS06/80814026 ''Library Factfiles: The murder of Sylvia Likens.''] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/65aUb7lAe?url=http://www.indystar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F99999999%2FNEWS06%2F80814026# |date=2012-02-20 }} The Indianapolis Star. Access date: November 14, 2007. In 1971, Gertrude and Paula Baniszewski were granted another trial by the [[Supreme Court of Indiana|Indiana Supreme Court]], largely for reasons of a prejudicial atmosphere due to heavy news media publicity before and during the trial.Unnamed author: "Court Orders New Trial in Likens Slaying", ''The Indianapolis Star'', September 2, 1970. Paula Baniszewski pleaded guilty to [[voluntary manslaughter]] and was released from prison one year later. Gertrude Baniszewski, however, was again convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison.Unnamed author: "Mrs. Baniszewski Meted Life in Likens Slaying", ''The Indianapolis Star'', August 20, 1971. Over the course of the next 14 years, Baniszewski became a model prisoner at the [[Indiana Women's Prison]], working in the sewing shop and becoming a "den mother" to younger female inmates. By the time she came up for parole in 1985, she was known by the prison nickname "Mom". The news of Baniszewski's parole hearing sent shockwaves through the Indiana community. Jenny Likens and her family appeared on television to speak out against Baniszewski; the members of two anti-crime groups, Protect the Innocent and Society's League Against Molestation, travelled to Indiana to oppose her parole and support the Likens family, beginning a sidewalk picket campaign. Over the course of two months, the groups collected over 40,000 signatures from the citizens of Indiana, including those who were too young to remember the case, demanding that Baniszewski be kept behind bars.Caleca, Linda Graham: "Baniszewski Ruling Won't Affect Past Parole Cases, Judge Says", ''The Indianapolis Star'', October 30, 1985Mermel, Marcy: "Mrs. Baniszewski Portrayed as a New Woman", ''The Indianapolis News'', December 3, 1985. Despite the efforts, Baniszewski was granted parole. During the hearing, she stated: "I'm not sure what role I had in it ... because I was on drugs. I never really knew her ... I take full responsibility for whatever happened to Sylvia." The [[parole board]], taking her [[Good conduct time|good behavior]] in prison into account, voted in favor of granting Baniszewski's freedom 3–2, and she was released. [[File:Gertrude-baniszewski002.jpg|thumb|Gertrude Baniszewski after leaving jail, aged 56.]] Baniszewski was released from prison on December 4, 1985, and traveled to [[Iowa]], where she called herself Nadine Van Fossan, using her middle name and maiden name. She lived in obscurity until her death in [[Laurel, Iowa]], from [[lung cancer]], on June 16, 1990, aged 60. When Jenny Likens, who was then married and living in [[Beech Grove, Indiana]], saw Gertrude Baniszewski's obituary in a newspaper, she clipped it and mailed it to her mother with the note: "Some good news. Damn old Gertrude died. Ha ha ha! I am happy about that."{{cite web|title=Suitcase of sorrow|work=The Indianapolis Star, Linda Graham Caleca (4-3-99)|url=http://www2.indystar.com/library/factfiles/crime/history/likens_sylvia/articles/040399.html|accessdate=2009-06-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719004707/http://www2.indystar.com/library/factfiles/crime/history/likens_sylvia/articles/040399.html|archivedate=2009-07-19|df=}} Jenny Likens Wade died of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] on June 23, 2004, at the age of 54. Richard Hobbs died of [[cancer]] on January 2, 1972, at the age of 21, four years after being released from the reformatory.{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/article/99999999/NEWS06/80814026/StarFiles-1965-murder-Sylvia-Likens|title=StarFiles: The 1965 murder of Sylvia Likens|publisher=Indystar.com|accessdate=2012-09-22}} After the [[Mitchell Johnson and Andrew Golden|Westside Middle School massacre]], John Baniszewski Jr., by then calling himself John Blake, made a statement claiming that young criminals are not beyond help and describing how he had turned his life around.[http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/18.html The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens: In Memoriam] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930100521/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/18.html |date=2012-09-30 }}; Crime Library.com He died of [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] at General Hospital in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]], on May 19, 2005, at the age of 52. Coy Hubbard, Stephanie Baniszewski's boyfriend (who had beaten Likens) was in and out of prison after his release. He was later charged with the murder of two men but was acquitted. He died of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] on June 23, 2007, at the age of 56 in [[Shelbyville, Indiana]]. Paula Baniszewski, the eldest of Gertrude's seven children, received a prison sentence of twenty years to life for her part in Likens' death. Her baby daughter, Gertrude, whom she gave birth to while incarcerated, was later [[Adoption|adopted]]. In 1971, she twice tried unsuccessfully to escape from prison.{{cite book |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=bg13QcMSsq8C |page=910 }} |title=The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis - David J. Bodenhamer, Robert Graham Barrows |publisher= |date= 1994-11-22|accessdate=2012-09-22|isbn=0253112494}} In 1972, she was paroled and assumed a new identity. She eventually married, has two children, and reportedly lives in a small town in Iowa today.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/iowa-teachers-aide-fired-role-grisly-1965-killing/story?id=17555655 |title=Teacher's Aide Fired for Revelation of Role in Grisly 1965 Killing |publisher=abcnews.go.com |date=2012-10-24 |accessdate=2012-10-24}} She worked as an aide to a [[school counselor]] for 14 years at the [[BCLUW Community School District|Beaman-Conrad-Liscomb-Union-Whitten (BCLUW) school district]] in Iowa, having changed her name to Paula Pace and lied to the school district when applying for the job. She was fired in 2012 when the school discovered her deception.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/23/school-aide-fired-after-c_1_n_2007567.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Iowa Teacher's Aide Fired After Discovery Of Connection To 1965 Torture, Killing Of Girl | date=2012-10-23}} The murder charge against Gertrude Baniszewski's second-eldest daughter, Stephanie (aged 15), was dropped after she [[Turn state's evidence|turned state's evidence]] against the other defendants. She assumed a new name and became a school teacher. She married and has several children.{{cite web |last=Noe |first=Denise |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/18.html |title=The Torturing Death of Sylvia Marie Likens — In Memoriam — Crime Library on |publisher=Trutv.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930100521/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/18.html |archive-date=2012-09-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The injury-to-person charges against the younger juveniles, Anna Ruth Siscoe, Judy Darlene Duke, Michael John (Mike) Monroe, Darlene McGuire, and Randy Gordon Lepper, were dropped. Siscoe married and had children and grandchildren; she died on October 23, 1996 at the age of 44. Lepper died on November 14, 2010 in [[Indianapolis]] at the age of 56.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/indystar/obituary.aspx?n=randy-g-lepper&pid=151636716#fbLoggedOut |title=THE INDIANAPOLIS STAR OBITUARIES: Complete listing of The Indianapolis Star Obituaries powered by Legacy.com |publisher=indystar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-22}} On May 10, 2015, Likens' sister Diana (who was using the name Dianna Bedwell) and her husband, Cecil Knutson, were reported missing by their son, Robert Acosta. Dianna and Cecil had been gambling at the [[San Pasqual Band of Diegueno Mission Indians|Valley View Casino]] in [[Valley Center, California]]. Surveillance video recorded the couple leaving the casino at about 2 p.m. by car, but they did not show up at their son's house in [[La Quinta, California|La Quinta]]. Acosta contacted the police and appeared on television, asking the public's help in finding his parents.{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/news/2015/05/13/sylvia-likens-older-sister-vanishes-california/27232635/|title=Archives: Sylvia Likens' older sister vanishes in California|publisher=}} On May 25, 2015, the couple was found in a mountainous area of an Indian reservation by members of a volunteer Jeep patrol. Cecil was dead and Dianna was severely dehydrated after surviving on just rainwater and some food. Dianna was airlifted to a hospital in serious condition. She told investigators they were looking for a shortcut when they got lost and became stuck on a rugged road.{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2015445/elderly-missing-couple-found-in-california-husband-dead/ |title=Elderly missing couple found in California, husband dead |publisher=globalnews.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-25}} The house at 3850 East New York Street in which Likens was tortured and murdered stood vacant and rundown for many years after the murder. Although there was some discussion of purchasing it for renovation and using it as a [[women's shelter]], the necessary funds were never raised. The house was demolished on April 23, 2009. The property is now a church parking lot. A {{convert|6|ft|m|-tall|adj=mid|spell=in}} block of granite was dedicated in June 2001 as a memorial to Likens in Willard Park, 1700 E. [[Washington Street (Indianapolis)|Washington Street]]. The dedication was attended by several hundred people.{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Will|title=Retro Indy: The Murder of Sylvia Likens, as told 50 years ago|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/news/crime/2015/10/23/indianapolis-most-sadistic-act-sylvia-likens-gertrude-baniszewski-torture-slaying-indianapolis-news-indianapolis-crime-crime-horror-torture/74209878/|accessdate=March 31, 2017|work=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|date=October 23, 2015}} ==Depictions== The case has since been the subject of numerous fictional and non-fictional accounts. ===Nonfiction=== ====Books==== * Author John Dean (also known as Natty Bumppo) wrote an account of the murder, ''The Indiana Torture Slaying: Sylvia Likens Torture and Death'' (later called ''House of Evil: The Indiana Torture Slaying''.){{cite book|last=Dean|first=John|title=House of Evil: The Indiana Torture Slaying|publisher=St. Martin's True Crime Library|date=2008-07-29|isbn=978-0-312-94699-9|url=http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/26293149.}} * Author Paul Donnelly documented the case in his book ''501 Most Notorious Crimes''. ====Television==== * The case was documented on the "Born Bad" episode of ''[[Deadly Women]]'' on the [[Investigation Discovery]] channel. ===Fiction=== ====Novels==== * Patte Wheat's ''By Sanction of the Victim'' is a fictional account, set in the 1970s.{{cite book|last=Wheat|first=Patte|title=By Sanction of the Victim|publisher=Major Books|year=1976|isbn=978-0-89041-077-6|oclc=78063000|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/20.html|access-date=2009-09-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831065642/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/20.html|archive-date=2009-08-31|dead-url=yes|df=}} * The artist and feminist author [[Kate Millett]] dealt with the subject in a number of works. She wrote a semi-fictional book relating to the incident, ''The Basement: Meditations on a Human Sacrifice''.Broeske, Pat H. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/14/movies/14broes.html A Midwest Nightmare, Too Depraved to Ignore]; ''New York Times'', 14 January 2007 * Mendal Johnson's only novel, ''Let's Go Play at the Adams','' in which a 20-year-old babysitter is kidnapped, tortured, and murdered by a handful of teens whom she had been assigned to sit, was influenced by this case.{{cite book|last=Johnson|first=Mendal|title=Let's Go Play at the Adams'|publisher=Panther|date=1974-01-01|isbn=978-0-586-04233-5|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/20.html|access-date=2009-09-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831065642/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/young/likens/20.html|archive-date=2009-08-31|dead-url=yes|df=}} * [[Jack Ketchum]]'s novel ''[[The Girl Next Door (Ketchum novel)|The Girl Next Door]]'' is loosely based on the murder, set in the 1950s. * Author [[Craig Silvey]] describes the case in the novel ''[[Jasper Jones]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.litcharts.com/lit/jasper-jones/characters|title=Jasper Jones Characters from LitCharts - The creators of SparkNotes|publisher=}} ====Films==== * [[The Girl Next Door (2007 film)|A film of the same name]] as Ketchum's book was released in 2007, with [[Blythe Auffarth]] in the main role. * The film ''[[An American Crime]]'', starring [[Catherine Keener]] as Gertrude Baniszewski, [[Ellen Page]] as Likens, [[Jeremy Sumpter]] as Coy Hubbard, and [[Evan Peters]] as Richard Hobbs, premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in 2007. ====Other==== * A play called ''Hey, Rube'' written by Janet McReynolds, was produced but never published.{{cite news |url=http://www.timescall.com/ramsey/storyDetail97.asp?ID=63 |title=Santa actor being investigated in Ramsey case |author=Regensberg, Pam |date=March 8, 1997 |publisher=''[[Longmont, Colorado]] Times-Call'' |accessdate=2008-08-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080516004635/http://www.timescall.com/ramsey/storyDetail97.asp?ID=63 |archivedate = 2008-05-16}} *Kate Millett's 1967 [[installation art]] ''Trap'', in a New York loft basement, was influenced by Likens' murder.Laurel Fredrickson, "Trap: Kate Millett, Japan, Fluxus and Feminism". ''Women & Performance: a journal of feminist theory'', Volume 19, Issue 3, 2009 Millett created another art installation in 1978, ''The Trial of Sylvia Likens'', that depicts a courtroom scene with the five defendants.The Devil's Tale. Retrieved 2010-04-24. ==See also== * [[List of murdered American children]] * [[Crime in Indiana]] * [[Murder of Junko Furuta]] * [[Murder of Shanda Sharer]] * [[Murder of James Bulger]] * [[Murder of Kelly Anne Bates]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|6190702|Sylvia Likens}} *[http://www.sylvialikens.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=7 Baniszewski Trial Transcript] *[http://sylvialikens.com/ Sylvia Likens "Home Page"] A website that contains photographs and other information about the case. {{DEFAULTSORT:Likens, Sylvia}} [[Category:1965 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Child abuse resulting in death]] [[Category:Child sexual abuse in the United States]] [[Category:Crime in Indianapolis]] [[Category:Murders]] [[Category:October 1965 events]] [[Category:Torture in the United States]] [[Category:Violence against children]] [[Category:Murder in Indiana]] [[Category:1965 in Indiana]] [[Category:1966 in Indiana]]

revision.text:
The '''Ontario College of Family Physicians''' is an organization in [[Ontario]] for family [[physicians]]. It is known for its review of the health effects of pesticides.
In 2004 researchers from the Ontario College of Family Physicians reviewed the epidemiological literature from 1992-2003 on health effects and concluded that "exposure to all the commonly used pesticides — phenoxyherbicides, organophosphates, carbamates, and pyrethrins — has shown positive associations with adverse health effects"<ref>Sanborn et al. (2004). [http://www.ocfp.on.ca/English/OCFP/Communications/CurrentIssues/Pesticides/default.asp?s=1 Systematic Review of Pesticide Human Health Effects]. Ontario College of Family Physicians.</ref> Shortly after its release the review was criticized by the UK's Advisory on Pesticides Committee,<ref>Coggon D. (2004). [http://www.pesticides.gov.uk/acp.asp?id=1389 Assessment of the Review by the Chairman of the Advisory Committee on Pesticides]. ACP.</ref> which the authors responded to.<ref>[http://www.pesticides.gov.uk/acp.asp?id=1462 Response from the Authors of the 'Ontario report'.].ACP.</ref> In 2007 related reviews were published in separate articles on the cancer effects<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bassil KL, Vakil C, Sanborn M, Cole DC, Kaur JS, Kerr KJ |title=Cancer health effects of pesticides: systematic review |journal=Can Fam Physician |volume=53 |issue=10 |pages=1704–11 |date=October 2007 |pmid=17934034 |pmc=2231435 |doi= |url=http://www.cfp.ca/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17934034}}</ref> and the non-cancer effects.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sanborn M, Kerr KJ, Sanin LH, Cole DC, Bassil KL, Vakil C |title=Non-cancer health effects of pesticides: systematic review and implications for family doctors |journal=Can Fam Physician |volume=53 |issue=10 |pages=1712–20 |date=October 2007 |pmid=17934035 |pmc=2231436 |doi= |url=http://www.cfp.ca/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17934035}}</ref>
==See also== *[[College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario]] *[[The College of Family Physicians of Canada]] *''[[Collège des médecins du Québec]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.ocfp.on.ca Official Website
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ontario College Of Family Physicians}} [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Ontario]] [[Category:Regulatory colleges]]
{{med-org-stub}}

{{Infobox organization | name = PT Foundation | native_name =Yayasan PT | native_name_lang =[[Malay language|Malay]] | named_after = | image = File:PT Foundation (Logo).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = File:KLLGBTCentre0.jpg | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = PT Foundation office in Chow Kit, [[Kuala Lumpur]]. | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation =1987 | founder = | founding_location = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] | extinction = | merger = | type =[[Nonprofit organization]] | status =Foundation | purpose =[[HIV/AIDS]] | professional_title = | headquarters = [[Kuala Lumpur]] | location = Jalan Ipoh Kecil
50350 Kuala Lumpur | coords = | region =[[Malaysia]] | services = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | sec_gen = | leader_title =Trustee | leader_name = Dato’ Rosie Tan | leader_title2 = Chairperson | leader_name2 = Hisham Hussein | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]]
