style="text-align:center;"|4.6 : 1 |- | ''[[World]]'' || style="text-align:center;"|'''10.7''' || style="text-align:center;"|'''10.7''' || style="text-align:center;"|1.7 : 1 |- |} [[File:Suicide world map - 2009 Total.svg|220px|thumb|World map of 1978-2008 suicide rates showing lack of information from many African countries.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120122021659/http://www.who.int/mental_health/prevention/suicide_rates/en/ Suicide rates per 100,000 by country, year and sex (Table)]. [[WHO]]. 2011. Archived on 22 January 2012.]] In 1999, death by self-inflicted injuries was the fourth leading cause of death among aged 15–44, in the world. In a 2002 study it's reported the countries with the lowest rates tend to be in [[Latin America]], '[[Muslim countries]] and a few [[Asian countries]]', and noted a lack of information from most [[African countries]] (see map). Data quality is to date a concern for suicide prevention policies. Incidence of suicide tends to be under-reported and misclassified due to both cultural and social pressures, and possibly completely unreported in some areas. Since data might be skewed, comparing suicide rates between nations can result in statistically unsound conclusions about [[suicidal behavior]] in different countries. Nevertheless the statistics are commonly used to directly influence decisions about public policy and public health strategies.{{cite web |author=Elizabeth Scowcroft |publisher=Samaritans |title=Suicide Statistics Report 2012 |url=http://www.samaritans.org/sites/default/files/kcfinder/files/Suicide%20Statistics%20Report%202012.pdf |website=www.samaritans.org|date=February 2012}} Of the 34 member countries of the [[OECD]], a group of mostly [[high-income economy|high-income countries]] that uses [[market economy]] to improve the [[Human Development Index]], [[South Korea]] had the highest [[suicide rate]] in 2009. In 2011 South Korea's Ministry of Health and Welfare enacted legislation coinciding with WSPD to address the high rate.{{cite news|last=Choi|first=Jung-yoon|title=South Korea to step up suicide prevention efforts: In 2009, 15,413 people took their lives, a rate that is three times higher than two decades ago. Officials plan to boost suicide prevention funding and install surveillance devices at key sites.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/08/world/la-fg-south-korea-suicide-20110909|accessdate=11 June 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=8 September 2011}} In 2008 it was reported that young people 15–34 years old in China were more likely to die by suicide than by any other mean, especially young Chinese women in rural places because of 'arguments about marriage'. By 2011 however, suicide rate for the same age group had been declining significantly according to official releases, mainly by late China’s urbanisation and migration from rural areas to more urbanised: since the 1990s indeed, overall national chinese suicide rate dropped by 68%.{{cite news|last=Reynolds|first=James|title=Chinese youth 'face suicide risk'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7608575.stm|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=BBC News, Beijing|date=10 September 2008}}{{ cite web|title=Back from the edge - A dramatic decline in suicides |website=economist.com |url=https://www.economist.com/news/china/21605942-first-two-articles-chinas-suicide-rate-looks-effect-urbanisation-back |date=28 June 2014}} According to [[World Health Organization|WHO]], in 2009 the four countries with the highest rates of suicide were all in [[Eastern Europe]]; Slovenia had the fourth highest rate preceded by Russia, Latvia, and Belarus.{{cite news|title=News Roundup: Ljubljana|url=http://www.sta.si/en/vest.php?s=a&id=1425769|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=Slovenska Tiskovna Agencija|date=9 October 2009}} This stays within findings from the start of the WSPD event in 2003 when the highest rates were also found in Eastern European countries.{{cite web|title=Celebrating the 1st World Suicide Prevention Day 10 September 2003|url=http://iasp.info/wspd/2003_wspd.php|work=Press Release|publisher=International Association for Suicide Prevention|accessdate=12 June 2012}} adapted from the chapter on "Self-Directed Violence" from the ''World Report on Violence and Health'', [[World Health Organization]], Geneva, 2002. As of 2015 the highest suicide rates are still in Eastern Europe, [[Korean Peninsula|Korea]] and the Siberian area bordering China, in [[Sri Lanka]] and the [[Guianas]], Belgium and few Sub-Saharan countries. According to WHO's Mental health Atlas released in 2014, no low-income country reported having a national [[suicide prevention]] strategy, while less than 10% of lower-middle income countries, and almost a third of upper-middle and high-income countries had. Focus of the WSPD is the fundamental problem of [[suicide]], considered a major public health issue in high-income and an emerging problem in low and middle-income [[developed countries|countries]].{{cite web|title=September 10 2013 World Suicide Prevention Day. Stigma: A Major Barrier to Suicide Prevention|url=https://www.iasp.info/wspd/pdf/2013/2013_wspd_brochure.pdf|accessdate=25 January 2018|website=iasp.org|date=10 September 2013}} Among high-income countries (besides South Korea) highest rates in 2015 are found across some [[Eastern Europe]]an countries, [[Belgium]] and [[France]], [[Japan]], [[Croatia]] and [[Austria]], [[Uruguay]] and [[Finland]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; margin-right:0; white-space: nowrap;" |+ '''Estimated numbers and rates of suicide by income group, 2012''' |- style="background:#ececec;" !class="unsortable"|[[World Bank|Income group]] (% of global pop)!!Suicides
(in thousands)!!Global %!!Rate!!Male:Female |- | High-income  (18.3%) || style="text-align:center;"|197|| style="text-align:center;"|24.5% || style="text-align:center;"|'''12.7''' || style="text-align:center;"|3.5 : 1 |- | Upper-middle-income  (34.3%) || style="text-align:center;"|192|| style="text-align:center;"|23.8% || style="text-align:center;"|'''7.5''' || style="text-align:center;"|1.3 : 1 |- | Lower-middle-income  (35.4%) || style="text-align:center;"|333|| style="text-align:center;"|41.4% || style="text-align:center;"|'''14.1''' || style="text-align:center;"|1.7 : 1 |- | Low-income  (12.0%) || style="text-align:center;"|82|| style="text-align:center;"|10.2% || style="text-align:center;"|'''13.4''' || style="text-align:center;"|1.7 : 1 |- | ''Global''  (100.0%) || style="text-align:center;"|804|| style="text-align:center;"|100.0% || style="text-align:center;"|'''11.4''' || style="text-align:center;"|1.9 : 1 |- |} [[File:Income groups 2014-2016 by GNI per capita.png|180px|thumb|Countries by income group]] [[Socioeconomic status]] plays an important role in suicidal behavior, and wealth is a constant with regards to Male–Female suicide rate ratios, being that excess male mortality by suicide is generally limited or non existent in low- and middle-income societies, whereas it is never absent in high-income countries (see table). Suicidal behavior is also subject of study for economists since about the 1970s: although national costs of suicide and suicide attempts (up to 20 for every one completed suicide) are very high, suicide prevention is hampered by scarce resources for lack of interest by mental health advocates and legislators; and moreover, personal interests even financial are studied with regards to suicide attempts for example, in which insights are given that often "individuals contemplating suicide do not just choose between life and death [..] the resulting formula contains a somewhat paradoxical conclusion: attempting suicide can be a rational choice, but only if there is a high likelihood it will cause the attempter's life to significantly improve."{{small|{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/business/moneybox/2003/10/the_economics_of_suicide.html |title=The Economics of Suicide|website=Slate (magazine)}}{{cite journal |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/1061698|title=The Economics of Suicide |journal=Southern Economic Journal |date=Jan 2003 |volume=69|issue=3|pages=628–643 |doi=10.2307/1061698}}}} In the United States alone, yearly costs of suicide and suicide attempts are comprised in 50-100 billion dollars.{{small|{{cite web|url=https://www.sprc.org/about-suicide/costs/|title=Costs of Suicide|website=Suicide Prevention Resource Center}}{{cite web|url=https://afsp.org/about-suicide/suicide-statistics/|title=Suicide Statistics — AFSP|website=American Foundation for Suicide Prevention}}}} The United Nations issued 'National Policy for Suicide Prevention' in the 1990s which some countries also use as a basis for their assisted suicide policies nevertheless the UN noted that [[suicide bombers]]' deaths are seen as secondary to their goal of killing other people or specific targets and the bombers are not otherwise typical of people committing suicide. According to a 2006 WHO press release, one third of worldwide suicides were committed with [[pesticide]]s, "some of which were forbidden by United Nations (UN) conventions."{{cite web|title=Press Conference by World Health Organization on Suicide Prevention |url=https://www.un.org/News/briefings/docs/2006/060908_Suicide.doc.htm|publisher=United Nations Department of Public Information|accessdate=11 June 2012|format=Press Conference|date=8 September 2006}} WHO urged the highly populated Asian countries to restrict pesticides that are commonly used in failed attempts, especially [[organophosphate]]-based pesticides that are banned by international conventions but still made in and exported by some Asian countries.{{cite news|title=Restrict pesticides to reduce suicides: WHO |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/story/2006/11/09/pesticide-suicides.html|accessdate=12 June 2012|newspaper=CBC News|date=9 November 2006}} WHO reports an increase in pesticide suicides in other Asian countries as well as [[Central America|Central]] and South America. It is estimated that such painful failed attempts could be reduced by legalizing controlled voluntary euthanasia options, as implemented in [[Switzerland]]. As of 2017, it is estimated that around 30% of global suicides are still due to pesticide self-poisoning, most of which occur in rural agricultural areas in low- and middle-income countries (consisting in about 80% world population).{{cite web|title=Restrict pesticides to reduce suicides: WHO |url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs398/en/|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=23 September 2017|date=August 2017}} In high-income countries consisting of the remaining 20% world population most common methods are firearms, hanging and other self-poisoning. ==Gender and suicide== {{main|Gender paradox in suicide}} [[File:Male-Female suicide ratios and rates 2015 (age-standardized).svg|thumb|350px|link=File:Male-Female suicide ratios and rates 2015 (age-standardized).svg#Summary|Male:Female ratios of suicide rates. Green means higher prevalence of male suicides. Below are the male and female standardised suicide rates used to derive the ratios. {{refbegin|2}} {{legend|#d1d1d1|No data}} {{legend|#8ef5ca|Less than '''1.0 : 1'''}} {{legend|#9afc9e|Less than '''1.7 : 1'''}} {{legend|#70b873|Less than '''3.0 : 1'''}} {{legend|#478f4c|Less than '''4.0 : 1'''}} {{legend|#2a5e14|Above (or equal to) '''4.0 : 1'''}} {{refend}} ]] [[Europe]]an and [[Americas|America]]n societies report a higher male mortality by suicide than any other, while various [[Asia]]n a much lower. According to most recent data provided by WHO, about 40,000 females of the global three hundred thousand female suicides and 150,000 males of the global half million male suicides, deliberately take their own life every year in [[Europe]] and the [[Americas]] (consisting of about thirty percent world population).{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/gho/mental_health/suicide_rates_male_female/en/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170429062418/http://www.who.int:80/gho/mental_health/suicide_rates_male_female/en/ |archive-date=29 April 2017 |title=Age-standardized rates, male:female ratio |publisher=[[WHO]] |year=2015|accessdate=20 October 2018}} {{As of|2015}}, apart from a few South and East Asian countries home to twenty percent of world population, Morocco, Lesotho, and two Caribbean countries, because of changing [[sociology of gender|gender roles]] suicide rates are globally higher among [[men]] than [[women]]. {{Quote|''Even though women are more prone to suicidal thoughts than men, rates of suicide are higher among men. On average, there are about three male suicides for every female one – though in parts of Asia, the ratio is much narrower.'' ([[WHO]], 2002){{cite web |author=WHO |title=Self-directed violence|url=http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/violence/world_report/factsheets/en/selfdirectedviolfacts.pdf |website=www.who.int |date=2002}}}} {{Quote|''The disparity in suicide rates has been partly explained by the use of more lethal means and the experience of more aggression and higher intent to die, when suicidal, in men than women.'' ([[International Association for Suicide Prevention|IASP]], 2012)}} {{Quote|''There are many potential reasons for different suicide rates in men and women: gender equality issues, differences in socially acceptable methods of dealing with stress and conflict for men and women, availability of and preference for different means of suicide, availability and patterns of alcohol consumption, and differences in care-seeking rates for mental disorders between men and women. The very wide range in the sex ratios for suicide suggests that the relative importance of these different reasons varies greatly by country and region.'' ([[WHO]], 2012){{cite web |author=World Health Organization |title=Preventing suicide - A global imperative |url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/131056/9789241564878_eng.pdf#page=27 |website=www.who.int|date=2014}}}} In [[Western world|western]] countries men are about 300% or thrice as likely to die by suicide than females, while a few countries (counting over a hundred million residents overall) exceed the 600% figure. Most considerable difference in male–female suicide ratios is noted in countries of the former Soviet Bloc and in some of Latin America.{{cite web |author=Jodi O'Brien (Editor)|publisher=SAGE Publications |title=Encyclopedia of Gender and Society (p. 817)|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Lr91AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT869&lpg=PT869&dq=gender+paradox+suicidal+behavior&source=bl&ots=KYNsuHKSuX&sig=DIb32dcIYk2eHlTcFOHcS7Bgpxk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiMxaqsxMnZAhXLFsAKHQhPBkYQ6AEIhQIwHQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |date=2009}} Globally, in 2015 women had higher suicide rates in eight countries. Due to permanence of [[Globalization and women in China|traditional gender roles]], in [[China]] (almost a fifth of world population) women were up to 30% more likely than men to commit suicide and up to 60% in some other [[South Asian]] countries: overall South [[Asia]]n (including [[South-eastern Asia|South-Eastern]] Asia, a third of world population) [[age-adjusted]] ratio however, was ''around'' global average of 1.7 : 1 (men being around 70% more likely than women to die by suicide). Some suicide reduction strategies do not recognize the separate needs of males and females.{{cite journal | author=Payne, Sarah| title=The social construction of gender and its influence on suicide: a review of the literature | journal=Journal of Men's Health | volume=5 | issue=1 | pages=23–35 | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1875686708000146 | doi=10.1016/j.jomh.2007.11.002|display-authors=etal}} Researchers have recommended aggressive long-term treatments and follow up for males that show indications of suicidal thoughts. Studies have also found that because young females are at a higher risk of attempting suicide, policies tailored towards this demographic are most effective at reducing overall rates. Shifting cultural attitudes about [[gender roles]] and [[social norms]], and especially ideas about [[masculinity]], may also contribute to closing the gender gap: social status and working roles are assumed to be crucial for men's identity.{{cite journal | author=Thompson, Martie| title=Examining Gender Differences in Risk Factors for Suicide Attempts Made 1 and 7 Years Later in a Nationally Representative Sample | journal=Journal of Adolescent Health | volume=48 | pages=391–397 | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1054139X1000368X | doi=10.1016/j.jadohealth.2010.07.018|display-authors=etal}}{{cite web |author=Mette Lyberg Rasmussen |publisher=Norwegian Institute of Public Health - University of Oslo, Norway |title=Suicide among Young Men: Self-esteem regulation in transition to adult life |url=https://www.duo.uio.no/bitstream/handle/10852/46008/dravhandling-%20Rasmussen.pdf?#page=20 |date=2013}} ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[American Foundation for Suicide Prevention]] * [[National Survivors of Suicide Day]] * [[National Suicide Prevention Week]] * [[Suicide prevention]] * [[Suicide crisis]] * [[Samaritans (charity)]] * [[International Association for Suicide Prevention]] * [[American Foundation for Suicide Prevention]] * [[Suicide Prevention Action Network USA]] * [[Campaign Against Living Miserably]] * [[National Suicide Prevention Lifeline]] * [[SOSAD Ireland]] }} ==Notes== {{notelist}} {{notelist-lr}} {{Reflist|group="note"}} == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.iasp.info/wspd/index.php World Suicide Prevention Day at IASP] * [http://www.who.int/mediacentre/events/annual/world_suicide_prevention_day/en/index.html World Suicide Prevention Day at WHO] * [http://www.wspd.org.au World Suicide Prevention Day in Australia] * [http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=readall&cid=8187&Itemid=40872&lang=en World Suicide Prevention Day in the Americas] [[Category:Health awareness days|Suicide]] [[Category:Disability observances]] [[Category:Mental health]] [[Category:September observances]] [[Category:Suicide prevention]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]] [[Category:International observances]] [[Category:Observances]]

{{orphan|date=December 2010}} '''Your Candidates–Your Health''' is an initiative launched by [[Research!America]] and partner organizations to inform voters of their presidential and congressional candidates’ views on health and research.<ref name="YCYH">[http://www.yourcandidatesyourhealth.org/ Your Candidates–Your Health website.]</ref> The resource is a free, online voter education tool featuring candidates’ responses to questions about health and research.<ref>[http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2006/edition_10-22-2006/Intelligence_Report Lyric Wallwork Winik. “Intelligence Report.” PARADE. October 22, 2006. Accessed March 11, 2008.]</ref>
In 2006, all candidates for the United States [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] were invited to respond to a 10-question survey on several health and research issues, including [[stem cell]] research, research funding and global competitiveness in innovation.<ref name="KXnet">[http://www.kxmc.com/t/george-bush/45814.asp KXnet.com. “2006 Elections: Medical Research & U.S. Competitiveness Key Issues for Voters & Candidates.” September 18, 2006. Accessed March 11, 2008.]</ref> Candidates' responses, along with the public’s view on the same questions, were posted on the ''Your Candidates–Your Health'' website and were available to educate voters’ decisions in the [[United States general elections, 2006|2006 congressional elections]].<ref name="KXnet"/>
The initiative continued in 2007 with attention shifted to the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 United States presidential election]]. Presidential candidates from both parties were asked 17 questions in a survey on health, research and other related issues.<ref>[http://capwiz.com/pan/issues/alert/?alertid=10723311 Parkinson’s Action Network. Accessed March 11, 2008.]</ref> The questionnaire covered topics such as the [[Health care in the United States|American health care system]] and its costs; [[Health insurance in the United States|health care coverage]]; [[electronic health records]]; [[global health]]; [[stem cell]] research; global competitiveness in innovation; and funding for the [[National Institutes of Health|National Institutes of Health (NIH)]], the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)]], the [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality|Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ)]] and the [[Food and Drug Administration|Food and Drug Administration (FDA)]].<ref name="YCYH"/>
The nonpartisan initiative was advertised in key primary states in early 2008.<ref>[http://www.baltimoresun.com Jonathan D. Rockoff. “Science Campaigns for Cash: Researchers Want Presidential Hopefuls to Commit More Funds.” Baltimore Sun. October 22, 2007.]</ref> As part of its promotion, voters were asked to contact candidates and encourage them to respond to the survey.<ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/ Donald Kennedy. “The Real Debate.” Science. February 1, 2008.]</ref> Presidential candidate Senator Barack Obama and Senator [http://www.yourcandidatesyourhealth.org/john_mccain_medical_research_positions.php John McCain] responded.
The initiative is now collecting responses from the 2012 presidential and congressional candidates. As March 2012, responses from [http://www.yourcandidatesyourhealth.org/profile.php?c_id=NTUwMA%3D%3D President Barack Obama] and presidential candidate [http://www.yourcandidatesyourhealth.org/profile.php?c_id=NTQ5NA%3D%3D Newton Gingrich] are available.
== External links == * [http://www.yourcandidatesyourhealth.org/ Your Candidates–Your Health] * [http://www.researchamerica.org/ Research!America]

[[Category:Health in the United States]]
